llama3.polished_text:
The best ways of getting out of class are always the most legitimate ways. Next time you have to go to the doctor, the dentist, or make some other kind of appointment, schedule it for the day and time of the class you hate the most. This way, you'll be able to miss it without sneaking around. If your parent usually schedules appointments for you, go ahead and do it yourself beforehand. Then, make like everything's already taken care of.

In middle and high school, some teachers will write up passes for students to work on group projects in their classroom, especially during study hall or other break periods. If the project is especially important, you might be able to convince one teacher to write a pass for you to leave the class you don't like. Try to get teachers from different departments, like a shop teacher and a math teacher, who may not communicate with each other.

Depending on the class you're trying to get out of, you may have a more legitimate reason to leave than you originally thought. If you're annoying about being in a particular class, tell your teacher that you do better work in the library and ask if you can study there instead. Teachers are likely to be surprised by this, and you might win a free hour in the library.

If you're upset about something, or if you feel like you need to miss class for a more serious reason, ask to go talk to the guidance counsellor. Guidance counsellors are there to help you with school-related stress and pressure. Tell your teacher that you're really upset, but be vague. Talk quietly and seriously, right before class, and ask if they'll allow you to go talk to the guidance counsellor instead of coming to class today.

If you have to come up with an excuse, try to think of something they'll be unable to verify. No dead grandmothers. Try something like, "I think I might be having a panic attack," instead. Maybe you've got strict parents, but you never know until you ask. If you've got a real bummer of a class period coming up, ask one of your more lenient parents if they'll call you out for a class period sometime. You might get lucky once or twice.

Sometime, try doing a little research by asking one or both of your parents if they ever cut class when they were younger. Dig up some good stories, then use this for leverage later. If you find out your dad used to cut all the time because his math teacher was totally boring, start playing up how dull your math teacher is, and how you wish you could just come home and spend time cleaning up instead of going to class. Boom. Easy call-out.

llama3.polished_text:
**Creating a Safe Environment for Your Toddler**

Designate a safe play area for your toddler by removing hazardous objects and securing the space with a baby gate. This can be a specific room or area in your home.

**Kitchen Safety**

The kitchen can be a hazardous zone for toddlers. To prevent accidents, install a baby gate to block access to the kitchen. This will also allow you to work in the kitchen while keeping an eye on your child in the next room.

**Toys and Playtime**

Choose toys suitable for your child's age, focusing on soft toys without small parts that could break off or sharp edges that could cut. Ensure any objects within reach are stable and secure.

**Chemical Safety**

Toxic household chemicals, such as sulfuric and phosphoric acid, chlorine, ammonia, formaldehyde, and phenol, can be hazardous if ingested. Store these chemicals in a locked room or out of reach of your child.

**Houseplants and Decorations**

Some household plants, like Aloe Vera, Chrysanthemums, and Philodendron, are toxic if eaten. Choose non-toxic plants or keep them out of reach. Also, avoid using stones as decorations to prevent choking or injury.

**Fireplace Safety**

Secure your fireplace with a fence or grate and pad sharp edges and corners. If your child tends to play near the fireplace, consider not using it until they are older and understand fire safety.

**Medication Safety**

Be cautious of over-the-counter medications and prescriptions kept in purses or accessible areas. Toddlers should never be allowed to play with purses, as medications can be detrimental to their small bodies.

By following these guidelines, you can create a safer environment for your toddler to play and explore.

When starting training, begin with brief sessions, around five minutes long, and incrementally increase the duration as your dog becomes more engaged and focused to ensure a steady learning pace. To prevent confusion and ensure a seamless learning experience, start by teaching one command at a time, allowing your dog to thoroughly master each one before progressing to the next, which also helps to prevent overwhelming your dog with too much information at once. A well-defined goal or sequence of commands is essential to guide your dog through a progressive and efficient learning process, providing direction and structure to training sessions, and helping to prevent misunderstandings. By following a structured training plan, you can expedite your dog's learning process, strengthen the bond between you and your dog, and develop a lifelong friendship based on trust, understanding, and mutual respect. With patience, consistency, and positive reinforcement, your dog will become a well-behaved companion, and you'll be proud of the progress you've made together as you watch your dog grow into a loyal and loving friend, who will thrive on the rewards and praise they receive for good behavior. Remember to be patient and consistent in your training, rewarding your dog with praise and treats for good behavior, which encourages desired actions and fosters a strong, loving relationship that will last a lifetime.

llama3.polished_text:
Training your dog with voice commands is a crucial aspect of his development, as it will help him become a better and well-behaved dog throughout his life. When you first start training him, keep the sessions short, around five minutes, to avoid overwhelming him. It's essential to begin with one command at a time until he learns it, then move on to another. Repeat these sessions three times a day as you train him, and gradually increase the time as he gets older.

The first lesson that your puppy should learn is 'no' or 'stop,' as it will be easier for you to pick one or the other since they basically mean the same thing. Your puppy won't understand the meaning until you teach him, so make sure you are always firm with this command, but never hit him. When you see your puppy doing something he shouldn't, tell him 'no' or 'stop,' then pull him away from the activity and repeat the command until he obeys you consistently.

As your puppy starts to explore the world around him, he will try to chew and bite everything. When playing with him and he goes to bite or chew on you, tell him 'no bite' and offer a chew toy instead. This will help him associate this behavior with toys instead of your fingers. Repeat this process if you find him chewing objects he shouldn't, such as shoes or furniture, by saying 'no chew' until he does it consistently.

Teaching your puppy the 'sit' command is one of the most helpful commands to start with. To begin, stand in front of your puppy with a treat in your hand that he can see, firmly tell him to 'sit,' then gently push his bottom down until he is sitting. Once he is in the sitting position, give him the treat and praise him. Repeat this process until he can do it on his own without your help.

The 'sit' command works well to stop your puppy from jumping as well. Use a leash or your hands to gently pull him back, then give him the sit command and a tasty treat when he complies. He will soon learn that he shouldn't jump. Once he has mastered many of the other commands, you can teach your dog to lay down. You can either say 'down' or 'lay down' for this command.

To start, stand or sit facing your dog with a treat in your hand he can see, tell him 'down' or 'lay down' as you move your hand with the treat down towards the floor. As he starts to lay down, even if it's only a little bit, give him the treat and praise him. Keep trying until he lies down completely on the floor consistently.

The 'stay' command is one of the best to help with your puppy's safety. When your puppy is sitting in front of you, hold your hand in front of his face as wide as you can and firmly say 'stay,' then start backing away slowly. If he starts coming towards you, command him to sit again and give him praise, then repeat the process until he stays on his own.

Another command that can help your dog stay safe is 'come.' Start out slow while you are playing in the yard, lean down, and slap your thighs, saying 'come' in a friendly voice. He will think you want to play, so he will come running to you. Give him a treat and praise him. Repeat this command at different times, especially when your puppy may be distracted by a toy, another dog, or another human.

The 'quiet' command can help you stop your dog from barking at the wrong times. Keep a bag of treats handy for when he starts barking, look at him with a treat in your hand, and say 'quiet.' As soon as he stops barking, give him the treat and praise him. If he doesn't stop right away, show him the treat to try to get him to stop, then repeat until he stops as soon as you say the command.

As your dog ages, make sure to keep his training steady, even after he learns all the commands, play with him, and call out random commands. When he does as he is told, give him praise and treats, which will keep him sharp and make him a better, more well-behaved dog as he ages.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Spectral clustering first constructs a pairwise similarity matrix and then uses the top eigenvectors of W (after normalization) to embed the data into a low-dimensional space, where k-means is employed to group the data into k clusters. This process, as described by von Luxburg (2007), effectively adapts to nonconvex geometries and accurately separates various non-intersecting shapes. Spectral clustering can be particularly useful for separating non-intersecting shapes, and its simplicity belies its ability to tackle complex tasks. The method has been successfully applied to tasks such as image segmentation (Shi and Malik, 2000) and document clustering (Dhillon, 2001), often outperforming traditional methods like k-means. Spectral clustering has a rich theoretical foundation, as detailed by von Luxburg (2007), with connections to kernel k-means (Dhillon et al., 2004) and other areas of study, including random walk (Meila and Shi, 2001), graph cut (Shi and Malik, 2000), and spectral graph theory (Chung, 1996).

llama3.polished_text:
Spectral clustering is a widely used method for grouping data into clusters, particularly effective for non-convex geometries and non-intersecting shapes. The method involves constructing a pairwise similarity matrix and using the top eigenvectors to embed the data into a low-dimensional space, where k-means is employed to group the data into k clusters. Despite its simplicity, spectral clustering has been successfully applied to various tasks, such as image segmentation and document clustering, often outperforming traditional methods like k-means.

However, the high computational cost associated with the n x n matrix W, especially for large data sets, has led to the development of fast and approximate algorithms. Many of these algorithms use a landmark set to reduce the computational complexity of spectral clustering. Specifically, they first find a small set of data representatives, called landmarks, and then form an affinity matrix between the given data and the landmarks.

To improve scalability, different methods use the affinity matrix in various ways. For instance, column-sampling spectral clustering (cSPEC) regards the affinity matrix as a column-reduced version of W and uses the left singular vectors to approximate the eigenvectors of W. However, this method seems to consider only unnormalized spectral clustering, and it is unclear how to extend it to normalized spectral clustering. Another example is landmark-based spectral clustering (LSC), which uses a row-sparsified version of the affinity matrix as approximate sparse representations of the input data.

In this work, we propose a novel landmark-based scalable spectral clustering approach by adapting the co-clustering framework for landmark-based clustering and combining it with diffusion maps. Specifically, we first construct a bipartite graph with the given data and the landmarks, and form edges between each data point and its nearest neighbors in the landmark set. We then compute the transition probabilities for all vertices and use them to define a random walk on the bipartite graph, which generates a diffusion process. The resulting diffusion coordinates are expected to capture the global geometry of the clusters at different scales and strengthen the connectivity of each cluster.

We will show that the diffusion coordinates can be computed directly from the n × m matrix A, and propose three different ways to use the diffusion coordinates for clustering the data in X, depending on the length of the random walk. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 reviews the necessary background, Section 3 presents our methodology, and Section 4 presents the experiments conducted to test our proposed algorithms. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section 5.

trips_llama3.polished_text: About three weeks ago, a significant event occurred in my life. This event was one I'll never forget, and its impact still resonates with me. I often wake up and ponder our true purpose in life and how we respond when called upon. Things happen in our lives that we don't fully understand, and this can leave us with more questions than answers. We don't have complete control over all aspects of our lives, and this reality can be unsettling. The element of surprise can always catch us off guard, impacting our actions at any time and place. Recently, I experienced a sudden and unexpected event that called me to action without warning. This encounter proved to me that our worth as human beings is often determined by what we know, and that knowledge can be a powerful lifesaver. One particular morning, I stopped into a major store to check on something I was interested in purchasing. I was there for no other reason that day, but perhaps there was a greater purpose at play. It's possible that I was guided there to be in place for my contribution to mankind. As I browsed through the store, I noticed someone seemed agitated and irrational in their interaction with another person. I didn't give it much thought and continued with my shopping. However, it soon became clear that this person was experiencing a medical issue due to their behavior and apparent breathing problems. I'm CPR certified and trained to handle medical emergencies, which was fortunate given the circumstances. There was no one else around to help, so I intervened immediately to assess the situation. The person in distress was an elderly man who had just collapsed, struggling to breathe and respond coherently. I quickly instructed the closest person to call 911 and get help as fast as possible. I then evaluated the situation and began administering CPR until the medics arrived. The man wore a medical bracelet, which I instructed the caller to share with the 911 center to prepare the medics. It felt like an eternity to save this man's life, but the relief was immense when the EMS team took over. In the end, the man recovered without severe consequences and was doing well after a short hospital stay. This experience gave me a new perspective on life, highlighting how fragile we are. I still wonder what would have happened to that old man if I hadn't been there to help him in his time of need.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Take classes offered at your school that focus on technology and computer science. Enroll in computer programming, physics, and chemistry classes, and take as many math classes as possible. This is especially helpful if you are a high school student interested in pursuing a career in computer security. You can even try to take Advanced Placement (AP) courses to help put you ahead when you reach the college level. Most high schools and junior highs have some kind of computer club that students can join and participate in. This is a great way to start developing your more advanced experience with computer technology, which will also look good on your college application. You might also consider joining the robotics club at school for more experience with how technology and machinery can be integrated into the real world. Most computer security experts are now pursuing a bachelor's degree in a computer or IT-related major, as it provides a strong foundation in computer programming, networking, information systems, penetration testing, and systems analysis, which are essential skills for a career in computer security. Focus on choosing a high-quality program with the most up-to-date information on computer programming, networking, information systems, penetration testing, and systems analysis. For some computer security positions, it’s possible to get your foot in the door with an associate's degree accompanied by many years of experience, which can be a substitute for a bachelor’s degree. With an associate’s degree, you’ll spend less time and money on your education. However, you may have to start out in a lower entry-level position if you don’t have a bachelor’s degree. Make sure you choose a program that values innovation and aims to teach students the most relevant and useful information. Talk to your high school teachers and guidance counselors for help in finding a college with programs that fit your interests. To get an idea about your prospective university’s stance on these issues, consider reaching out to a current professor in a technology-related department to ask what they think about the value the university places on innovation. Consider getting a Master’s degree in computer sciences, IT systems, or even engineering. This is especially helpful if you have an undergraduate degree in an unrelated field, but it will also set you apart from the rest of the job hunters who have only a bachelor’s degree. This will give you the conceptual and theoretical background necessary to qualify you to work as a computer security consultant. Microsoft (MCSE), Cisco (CCIE), and other companies provide training and certification programs. Any consultant should be able to show a high level of certified training, as it will improve your chances of getting contracts. You can get many of these certifications by taking online training modules with accompanying exams. There are also many testing centers (often operated by Google or Microsoft) that facilitate these types of certifications. Some certifications are free, while others can cost anywhere from $200 to $2,000 USD, depending on the level of training and support needed, with some requiring only the exam and others including comprehensive training courses that can cost up to $2,000 USD. Training courses typically last anywhere from one day to several weeks, depending on the certification. Other useful certifications include: Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP), Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH), ITIL, Certified Information Security Manager (CISM), SANS GIAC, Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA), Project Management Professional (PMP), Certified Business Continuity Professional (CBCP), Certified Protection Professional (CPP) and Certified Information Privacy Professional (CIPP). Local chapters of these kinds of professional organizations can help you join study groups, forums, and conferences. They can also help enhance your resume and your expertise, and provide valuable networking opportunities and access to industry resources. Professional organizations are usually located in most larger cities, but function on a regional/national (or even international) level, which means that members can live anywhere and still participate. Two of the biggest organizations in the field are the Information Systems Security Association and the American Society for Industrial Security. Most organizations like this cost about $200 USD to join for an annual membership fee, though they often have discounts for students and retirees.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's a revised version of the text with improved fluency:

Text classification to derive insights has been widely used in various industries. It involves analyzing product or movie reviews to determine the overall sentiment. Other applications include analyzing tweets to gauge a brand's perception or people's views on a specific topic. These tasks can be boiled down to classification or summarization.

State-of-the-art NLP techniques perform well on single-language texts but may struggle with code-mixed texts due to limited labeled data. Code-mixed texts have become relevant, particularly with the rise of social media platforms. In a multi-lingual country like India, people often mix local languages with English while using social media. Code-mixing allows for easier communication by borrowing terms from different languages.

This results in code-mixed text, where local terms or entities are described in local languages. To understand such text, it's essential to identify the language used in different parts, followed by language-specific processing. In this work, we present different approaches for language identification in code-mixed text.

In code-mixed text, languages can be interleaved in various forms. For example, "this is not union budget, ye to aam admi ka budget hai" is a mix of English and Hindi. Another example is "maine aaj WhatsApp and Facebook uninstall kiya h," which is a mix of Hindi and English. Determining the language of individual words can be challenging, as the same word can be used in both languages depending on the context.

Social media text is often noisy, with words written in different ways to emphasize them. For instance, "good" can be written as "gooood." This requires considering different input representations, such as word, character, or sub-word. The sub-word representation is more recent and splits a word into logical units.

Our work focuses on evaluating the performance of these input representations. We explore sub-word based representations for Hi-En language identification, a novel approach. The task is to determine the language of each word in the sentence, formulated as a token classification task.

We use simple deep learning models, such as CNNs and LSTMs, in combination with different input representations to evaluate their effectiveness. These models are often used with CRFs to improve performance. However, our work restricts itself to simple architectures and focuses on input representation. We show that sub-word based representation coupled with simple models performs better than complex architectures reported in the literature.

Simple architectures are favorable as they reduce runtime speed and complexity. The language identification module should be fast and efficient, as it will often be followed by other NLP modules. We experiment with single-layer CNN and LSTM models and show that these architectures are sufficient to reach desired accuracy levels.

Our contributions include evaluating the effectiveness of character, sub-word, and word-based representations for Hindi-English language identification and comparing the combinations of popular model architectures and input representations.

llama3.polished_text:
When it comes to real estate, property taxes are based on the value of the land. The more valuable the land, the higher the property taxes will be. 

The value of the land can change over time, which means your property tax liability can change too. This change happens even if your local government doesn't raise the tax rate. 

To find your property tax liability, you need to know the value of the land you own. You can usually find this information by contacting your local assessor's office or local tax authority. Many assessors also have online tools that allow you to look up your property's value based on your address. The assessor's office for Santa Clara County in California has a great example of this sort of tool.

You can also get home value estimates from financial institutions. For example, Chase Bank offers a free online home value tool. The value of a piece of land is determined by two things: the value of the land itself and the value of whatever is built on it (i.e., its improvements).

To find the total value of your property, you need to add these two values together. Your local assessor can usually provide both pieces of information. For example purposes, let's find the property taxes for a house in ABC County, USA. The county assessor values the land at $357,000, mainly due to its proximity to a vibrant downtown area and the convenience of two nearby freeways.

The assessor also values the house itself at $307,000. Adding these two values, the total value of our property is $357,000 + $307,000 = $664,000. In the next few steps, we'll use this value to find our property taxes.

Property tax is generally assessed as a percentage of the property's current value. The tax rate can vary over time depending on the needs of the taxing agency. This is why up-to-date information is crucial. You can usually get this information from your local tax authority.

For example, in Santa Clara County, California, tax rate summaries are available online for free. Many municipalities apply the tax rate "per mill," or per $1,000 in assessed value. One mill is just 1/10 of one cent. For practical purposes, we can say that 10 mills of something is the same as 1%.

For the purposes of our example, let's say that ABC County has a 10 mill levy on our property. This amounts to 1% of our property's total value. The local government isn't the only organization that relies on property tax revenues. Other organizations that serve the local community often require their own share of property taxes.

Notably, most public school districts get the majority of their revenue from local property taxes. Cities, towns, and other local entities may also require property taxes. In our example, let's say that the city of Appleton, where we live in ABC County, has its own 20 mill (2%) property tax and that the Appleton Unified School District levies its own property tax at a 30 mill rate (3%).

When you know all of the different property taxes you'll have to pay, finding your total liability is fairly easy. Start by adding up the different tax rates to get one total property tax rate that you'll need to pay. In our example, since we owe a 1% property tax to the county, 2% to the city, and 3% to the school district, we owe, in total, 1 + 2 + 3 = 6%.

To find the amount you owe in property tax, multiply your total property tax rate by the value of the property you are dealing with. Remember to change the percentage to its decimal form or divide your answer by 100 when multiplying. 

In our example, our total property tax rate is 6% and our property is worth $664,000. To find the amount we owe in taxes, we multiply 0.06 × $664,000 = $39,840.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Most songs in Western music are built around a set of common chord progressions based on the diatonic scale, which is a fundamental element of Western music theory. Once you know which progressions are most common in the music you listen to, you'll have a much easier time identifying them in songs you want to learn, as this knowledge will enable you to recognize patterns and connections between different melodies and harmonies. Diatonic chords are numbered with Roman numerals according to the position of the root note on the scale, with major chords represented by uppercase numerals, such as I, IV, and V, while minor chords are written with lowercase numerals, including i, ii, and iii. For example, the I chord on the C major scale is the C tonic chord, which is a fundamental element of Western music theory, consisting of the 1st, 3rd, and 5th notes of the C major scale, or C-E-G. Minor chords, on the other hand, are represented by lowercase Roman numerals and can be found in various keys, such as i, ii, iii, and vi, with the i chord being the minor tonic chord, which is the most common chord progression in Western popular music. One of the most common chord progressions in Western popular music is I-IV-V-I, a progression that has been widely used in countless songs across various genres, including rock, pop, and country. Try playing common chords and really listening to what they sound like, paying attention to the different timbres and textures that arise from the combination of notes played in each chord. Don't just stick to root positions, where the notes played are the 1st, 3rd, and 5th notes, or scale degrees, of the key; practice listening to inversions, too, such as 3rd, 5th, and 8th, which can add depth and complexity to your music. Listen to 7th, diminished, and augmented chords, as well as basic major and minor triads, which can add a wide range of colors and timbres to your music. The more you listen to the chords, the more familiar they will become, allowing you to recognize them in different musical contexts and to improvise with confidence. For example, in C Major, the root notes are C, E, and G, while E, G, and C are the 3rd, 5th, and 8th scale degrees, respectively, of the first inversion of C. Try quizzing yourself with a chord identification tool like Tonedear, which can help you develop your ear and improve your skills in recognizing chords in different musical contexts. Songs written in major keys tend to sound bright, upbeat, happy, or hopeful, while minor keys lend a gloomy, sad, or scary sound, creating a distinct emotional landscape for the listener. The easiest way to determine whether a song is major or minor is simply to listen to the overall "mood" of the piece, which can be influenced by the chord progression, melody, and other musical elements. While the chords in a minor key song will primarily be minor chords, there will likely be some major chords mixed in, creating a sense of tension and release. The reverse is also true of major key songs, which often feature a mix of major and minor chords to add depth and interest to the music. Once you've figured out the tonic chord, you will have a good foundation for figuring out the rest of the song, as the tonic chord serves as a reference point for the rest of the chord progression. Most songs end on the tonic (I) chord, and many also begin there, creating a sense of closure and completion for the listener. The tonic chord should be the predominant chord throughout the song, and hearing it will give you a sense of completion or satisfaction, making it a fundamental element of Western music theory. For example, "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star," when played in the key of C major, begins and ends on a C major tonic chord, creating a sense of closure and completion for the listener. In most songs, the bass line is the harmonic accompaniment to the melody, providing a foundation for the rest of the chord progression. The bass line tends to be built on the root notes of each chord in the song, creating a sense of harmonic structure and progression. This means that if you can figure out the notes of the bass "melody," you can pinpoint the root of each chord and build from there, creating a deeper understanding of the music. For example, if you are listening to "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" in C major, you may identify the notes C, F, C, F, C, G, C in the bass line of the first 4 measures, which are the root notes of the chords for those measures. These are the foundation notes of the chords for those measures, providing a harmonic structure and progression for the music. Once you've figured out the root notes, ask yourself about the quality of each chord, considering whether it sounds major or minor, and whether you hear tones other than the 1st, 3rd, and 5th notes of the chord, such as the 7th. After you've figured out the chords, play them in order, following the rhythm of the piece, which requires a deep understanding of the music and its various elements. You may find it helpful to play along with a recording of the song to make sure that you have the timing right, which is essential for creating a sense of forward motion and energy in the music. Depending on the type of instrument you're playing, this could mean playing the different parts together or playing the chords as accompaniment to a voice or a second instrument, which requires a high degree of musicianship and technical skill. Run through the song several times to make sure that your chord changes are timed correctly with the melody, which is essential for creating a sense of cohesion and unity in the music. For example, if you are playing the piano, you will probably play the chords primarily with your left hand while your right hand carries the melody, which requires a high degree of finger dexterity and coordination.

llama3.polished_text:
Significant advancements have been achieved in Large Language Models (LLMs) in recent years, making them a cornerstone of various applications in the field of natural language processing (NLP). These LLMs are typically pre-trained on a large corpus of natural language and then fine-tuned on specific downstream tasks' datasets to enhance their performance. Recent studies have demonstrated the success of LLMs can be attributed to their ability to act as knowledge bases, implicitly storing knowledge learned from training datasets in their parameters as internal memory and generating responses by retrieving answers from this memory. To further enhance their ability to store knowledge and generate responses, existing works have generally enlarged the memory capacity by increasing the volume of parameters, thereby improving their generation performance.

However, despite the significant advancements achieved by LLMs, there are several challenges hindering their development. One of the most prominent challenges is the hallucination problem, which refers to the tendency of LLMs to generate responses that are coherent and fluent but factually incorrect. Another significant challenge is the knowledge update issue, which necessitates the retraining or fine-tuning of LLMs with new data to update the knowledge stored in their internal memory. This process is often time-consuming and costly. Furthermore, general LLMs lack domain-specific expertise, making it challenging to apply them to specific domains without considerable manpower for dataset collection.

To address these challenges, recent studies have proposed leveraging an external knowledge database to augment LLMs, a technique known as retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). By supplying LLMs with retrieved relevant factual information, the hallucination problem can be alleviated to some extent. Moreover, the knowledge update issue can be addressed by updating the external knowledge database, which can augment LLMs with up-to-date knowledge. RAG can also convert a general LLM into a domain-specific LLM by constructing and utilizing a domain-specific knowledge database. The technique plays an essential role in augmenting the functionality of LLMs, making them more accurate, knowledgeable, and reliable in a wide range of applications.

Contributions of this paper include a comprehensive review of all techniques involved in RAG for natural language processing. Although several survey papers have been published on RAG, this paper still offers some key insights, including:

1. A systematic introduction to each component of RAG, including details about the retriever from building to querying, and techniques of the retrieval fusions with tutorial codes.
2. A discussion of different RAG training strategies, including RAG with/without datastore update.
3. An examination of the applications of RAG on downstream NLP tasks and practical NLP scenarios.
4. An identification of promising future directions for exploring and challenges for addressing.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows:

- Section 2 provides an overview of RAG.
- Section 3 and Section 4 comprehensively introduce all technical details used in retrievers and retrieval fusions.
- Section 6 presents how to train the RAG with/without new knowledge.
- Section 7 presents the techniques used in representative NLP tasks.
- Section 8 shows the applications of RAG in practical NLP scenarios.
- Section 9 discusses the future directions of RAG.
- Section 10 makes a final conclusion of this paper.

When choosing a bird cage, it is essential to consider the size of your bird and its needs. The cage should be at least 1.5 times the adult wingspan of your bird in width, depth, and height to allow for ample movement. In fact, bigger cages are even better, as they provide a spacious environment for your bird to fly and exercise freely. For a comprehensive guide to suggested cage sizes by bird species, visit bird-cage.com. Generally speaking, the minimum height of the cage should be three times the length from head to tail of the bird to accommodate its natural flight patterns. It is also crucial to have at least two wing beats between perches to prevent collisions and promote a safe environment. Your bird should be able to turn around comfortably on its perch without its tail feathers hitting the cage, ensuring its comfort and well-being. Even small birds, such as finches, require large cages to fly and exercise, with a recommended space of 3-4 square feet. Larger birds, like African greys and Amazons, also need plenty of space to fly and glide, making a long, low cage a better option than a narrow, high one.

When it comes to cage bars, the width is also a critical factor. Bars under ½ inch are suitable for small birds, such as finches, canaries, parrotlets, and parakeets, while medium birds, like cockatiels and conures, require bars that are ½ to ¾ inch in width. Larger birds, including African greys and Amazons, need bars that are ¾ to 1-1/4 inches wide. Adding more corners to the cage can actually decrease the flight area and make it less safe for your bird. Your bird will spend most of its time standing, so providing an adequate number of perches is vital to its health and happiness. A combination of natural and manmade perches is recommended, with a natural branch perch and a concrete perch being ideal. Natural branch perches are better than wooden dowels because they provide a more varied grip for your bird's feet.

When selecting perches, be sure to avoid those made from plastic or sandpaper, as they can cause problems if eaten or scratched your bird's feet. Concrete perches are a great option, as they provide a solid surface for your bird to groom. Manmade perches, such as untreated cotton rope, are also a good choice, as they are toxin-free and easy to clean. Your bird will spend countless hours trying to open the door to its cage, so it's essential to have an escape-proof door. You can use a padlock, clip, or small carabiner to secure the door and prevent escape attempts. Daily checks of your bird's seed and water supply are crucial, especially if a child is caring for the bird. Regular bathing is also essential to keep your bird's feathers and skin healthy, with room temperature water being a must to prevent stripping essential oils from your bird's feathers.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Transforming complex sentences into a sequence of shorter sentences, while preserving the original meaning, can facilitate the processing of complex texts for humans and machines alike. This includes an important operation in text simplification (Zhu et al., 2010; Narayan and Gardent, 2014; Shardlow, 2014), where simpler sentences can provide content that is easier to read and comprehend. Split and rephrase (SPRP) is a task that commonly refers to this operation (Narayan et al., 2017), providing a relevant framework to evaluate natural language processing models that need to tackle complex linguistic properties to provide optimal splits and suitable rephrasing. The SPRP task is typically performed via dedicated transformation models, such as sequence-to-sequence modelling with a copy mechanism (Aharoni and Goldberg, 2018) or graph-based neural segmentation (Gao et al., 2021). One of the main limitations of this approach is the reliance on limited training datasets of paired complex and split sentences, which are scarce across languages and domains. As an alternative, Kim et al. (2021) exploit one-to-many alignments in parallel corpora and pivot machine translation to create an aligned corpus of complex and split sentences, which can be utilized by sequence-to-sequence models. The main bottleneck of this approach is the dependence on parallel corpora with sufficient many-to-one alignments and high-quality pivot machine translation models. Large language models, such as GPT models (Radford et al., 2018) based on the Transformer architecture (Vaswani et al., 2017), have demonstrated strong potential on various downstream tasks, including model variants with and without instruction tuning (Radford et al., 2019; Brown et al., 2020). We measure the performance of these models on the SPRP task, prompting them to generate split and rephrase hypotheses from complex sentences. We evaluate the performance of different variants of our approach on datasets of varying complexity, comparing zero-shot, few-shot in-context learning, and fine-tuning scenarios. Notably, we measure the impact of model size, training data volume, domain shift, and prompt optimization. Our results demonstrate that large language models significantly outperform the previous state of the art across multiple metrics, with remaining relative deficiencies, notably in terms of split generation. Our results from two human evaluations, a comparative 3-way ranking task, and a qualitative evaluation support these conclusions and confirm the effectiveness of our approach. Our main contributions include establishing a new state of the art on the SPRP task, using publicly available datasets of varying complexity, across multiple metrics, and two human evaluations. This includes a comprehensive evaluation of large language models for SPRP, covering model variants with and without instruction tuning, as well as the impact of different prompting strategies, model size, training data volumes, and domain shift. We also provide empirical results on large language model strengths and limitations for SPRP, including splitting compliance and rephrasing variability.

This paper builds upon our previously published work, introducing several significant extensions to the Trend language, which enhances its capabilities and applications. We provide a comprehensive presentation of the full Trend language, which includes graphical, textual, and formal logic-based representations for precision and reference, offering users a range of options for data modelling. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows: Section 2 provides a concise overview of the related work in the field, and Section 5 presents the results of our experiments, which form the core of our contribution.

llama3.polished_text:
Temporal constraints in conceptual data models are crucial for numerous application domains, including temporal conceptual data modelling, business process modelling, data analytics, and designing append-only databases for blockchains, among others. Such a wide array of application scenarios would ideally be served by a very expressive temporal conceptual data modelling language (TCDML) that could be used throughout various application scenarios with a single effort of learning and easy reuse. However, most existing TCDMLs lack transition constraints for object migration, temporal attributes, or relation migration (among others, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]). Furthermore, none of them has been evaluated by users on preferences for diagram notation with temporal constraints, nor for understanding of a temporal model or ability to create a temporal conceptual data model.

Here, we include modellers in industry as well as undergraduate and postgraduate students in academia who have been taught conceptual modelling, thus reflecting a broader community who could benefit from the work presented. For this reason, there is, as a minimum, a need for an evaluation on fitness for purpose. In this paper, we aim to address this through the development of a TCDML that is grounded in the description logic language DLRUS and for which we designed and evaluated a graphical notation through a series of experiments. The resulting TCDML we called Trend, which stands for Temporal information Representation in ENtity-relationship Diagrams.

In so doing, we sought to answer the following questions: RQ1: What diagram notation is preferred for temporal elements and constraints? RQ2: How well is the resulting temporal conceptual model understood by modellers? RQ3: How well are modellers able to design such models? To answer these questions, we conducted three sets of experiments. The first was a series of progressive experiments to determine the 'best', or most preferred, notation of temporal information among the plethora of notations, using a qualitative reflective learning approach with participants mainly from industry and a moderately-sized evaluation with postgraduate students. 

The second set of experiments focused on model understanding and feedback on a few minor variants in notation for the transition constraint, among postgraduate students and a large cohort of undergraduate students. The third set of experiments zoomed in on the ability to design temporal conceptual models with a temporal conceptual data modelling language we designed, through varying the amount of explanation and the task to carry out, in three large-scale experiments with 200-450 participating students that are comparative novices in modelling, for increased statistical validity of the conclusions.

The qualitative evaluations led to a 'tentative' notation for our TCDML, Trend, and also indicated a need for some training on modelling temporal information. The quantitative experiments finalised and solidified the Trend notation. The experiments revealed that the labels for the transition constraints have little impact on correctness, but a graphical notation is clearly preferred over controlled natural language text. Temporal entity types, attributes, and dynamic extension are best used.

More extensive introductory notes did not assist substantially in modelling and understanding overall, although a marked increase in modelling in temporal attributes and relationships was observed. Better demarcation of the domain, in the form of a set of controlled natural language statements, did improve modelling quality of the temporal constraints. This paper extends our previously published work [6, 7] in a number of ways. While Trend was tested with a small number of participants in [7], here we summarise also the experiments leading up to that version and conduct large scale evaluations that also finalised the graphical notation.

In addition, the preliminary Trend was only sketched in [7], whereas here we present the full language—graphically, textually, and with its formal logic-based underpinning for precision and reference. We also provide an overview of the related work more comprehensively. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 summarises related work. Section 3 describes the first set of experiments and results to determine the preferred representation in extended ER diagrams. Section 4 and Appendix 7 introduce Trend and its formal foundation. Section 5 reports on the experiments on model understanding and ability to design. Section 6 discusses the work and Section 7 concludes.

Breaking curfew in the past can damage trust with your parents. The only way to build trust back is to stick to your curfew in the future. If you've broken curfew before, it's crucial to show your parents that you've learned from your mistakes.

llama3.polished_text:
This story took place within the last week, however it was many years in the making and I have endured many trials and tribulations along the way to say the very least. 

The events that transpired were a culmination of a long and winding road, one that was filled with countless moments of joy and an equal amount of heartache, but ultimately it was worth it for the memories we had created together. 

Many years ago a girl opened her heart to me, she told me things she said she had never told another soul, she felt that she could trust me more so than any other person in her life. 

She revealed to me intimate details about her past, about her fears and her dreams, and in doing so, she gave me a glimpse into the depths of her soul, a glimpse that I cherished dearly and held close to my heart. 

She meant the world to me, my whole soul lit up the moment she entered the room. 

The very air around me seemed to change when she walked in, it was as if the universe itself had shifted to make room for her, and I was forever changed by the experience. 

I felt myself really falling for her personality, her smile, her laugh. 

Her infectious laughter was like music to my ears, it was a sound that brought a smile to my face and a warmth to my heart, and I found myself drawn to her in a way that I had never experienced before. 

I was very honored that we were able to share time together, it really meant something to me and I hope that it had meant a lot to her as well. 

The time we spent together was a gift, a precious gift that I cherished every moment of, and one that I will always treasure in my heart. 

When she told me that she was moving cross country, I was heart-broken. 

The news hit me like a ton of bricks, leaving me feeling lost and alone, and I struggled to come to terms with the fact that she would be leaving me behind. 

I truly thought that she would be in my life forever and yet that was not the case at all. 

Time seemed to stand still as I grappled with the reality of her departure, and I found myself wondering if I would ever see her again. 

She had been assigned to a job which would take her away from me and possibly to new countries and new adventures. 

The thought of her venturing out into the world, meeting new people, and experiencing new things was exciting, but it was also bittersweet, as it meant that I would not be a part of her journey. 

I might never see her again and I felt that was almost too much for me to bear. 

The possibility of losing her forever was a prospect that I could hardly bear to think about, and it left me feeling empty and alone. 

We did keep in touch, and like I suspected, contact became less and less until it was almost gone completely. 

As time went on, our communication became less frequent, and eventually it seemed as though we had lost touch altogether, but I never gave up hope that we would reconnect someday. 

I went on with my life, found other people to spend my time with. 

I dated, and dated some wonderful people, but none really compared to her. 

Despite my best efforts to move on, I found that I was constantly comparing my relationships to the one I had shared with her, and I struggled to find anyone who measured up to her standards. 

I found she was on my mind, if only in the back of my mind as the gold standard to which anyone I met was compared against. 

The memories of her lingered, and I found myself constantly evaluating my relationships through the lens of our time together, and it was a difficult and often frustrating process. 

It was definitely difficult to compare and my relationships always suffered as a consequence of it. 

The weight of my unrequited love bore down on me, making it challenging to form meaningful connections with others, and I struggled to find happiness in my personal life. 

Then one day, just last week my life changed forever. 

I heard it first, that magical laugh that always captivated me. 

The sound of her laughter was like a key turning in a lock, unlocking a floodgate of emotions that I had thought were long buried, and I was immediately transported back to a time when life was simpler and love was new. 

I had to seek the source of the sound. 

My curiosity got the better of me, and I turned to see who was responsible for the laughter, and that was when I saw her, standing there with a huge smile on her lips. 

Although many years had passed, I could remember it like it was yesterday and so many feelings came flooding back. 

The memories came rushing back, and I was suddenly hit with a wave of nostalgia, and I felt like I was reliving the past all over again. 

When I turned around I discovered it was her - it was really her! 

I was stunned, shocked, and overjoyed all at once, and I couldn't believe my eyes - she was standing right in front of me, looking more beautiful than ever. 

She was standing there a huge smile on her lips. 

Her smile lit up the room, and I was immediately drawn to her, feeling a sense of connection and belonging that I hadn't felt in years. 

It look me by surprise I never thought I would see her again and yet there was was standing before me. 

The unexpected reunion was a shock to my system, and I struggled to process the fact that she was standing right in front of me, after all these years. 

We talked for hours as though we had never been apart. 

Our conversation flowed easily, like no time had passed at all, and we picked up right where we had left off, talking and laughing like old friends. 

To find out that she is moving back to our town, that she is single and still thinks of me as I had thought of her is almost a stroke of magic. 

The universe seemed to be conspiring in our favor, bringing us back together in a way that felt almost mystical, and I couldn't help but feel grateful and blessed. 

I look forward to the years to come and hope they are just as magical as the very first day I laid eyes upon her.

llama3.polished_text:
Proving theorems is one of the most fundamental goals in mathematics, requiring complex math reasoning and a rich store of math knowledge. Recently, large language models (LLMs) [15, 25, 20, 3, 6, 24, 33] have made great progress in solving grade-school [5] and even high-school level math problems [8] through chain-of-thought reasoning [28]. LLMs can also interact with proof assistants, including Lean [18], Coq [26], or Isabelle [21], to prove theorems. However, the performance of theorem proving with LLMs [34] is not satisfying, with one reason being data sparsity. The mainstream approach for LLMs in learning theorem proving is through expert iteration [1, 30, 14, 22, 31], where LLMs search for the proof in the given math problem and statement set, such as MiniF2F [34] and Mathlib [17], and learn from their success trajectories. However, the amount of data in MiniF2F is limited due to the significant labor required from human experts to formalize problems. Although Mathlib is a very large dataset containing the formalization of different math subjects in Lean, it primarily proves fundamental math theorems instead of contest-level problems. Therefore, an initial step towards a better automatic theorem-proving model is to create enough high-quality formalized statements. Towards this goal, we present Lean Workbook: an iterative autoformalization pipeline, accompanied by a large-scale Lean problem set. We train our autoformalization model based on active learning, leveraging the iterative process to refine the model's performance. ∗Work done during internships at Shanghai AI Laboratory. Submitted to the 38th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2024) Track on Datasets and Benchmarks. Do not distribute.

Figure 1: The data contribution of our Lean Workbook pipeline, which ensures the accuracy of output data through three rounds of filtering. By applying the pipeline to the AOPS and the Compfiles data sources, respectively, we derive 21 formalized IMO questions and about 57k synthetic training data for autoformalization. At each turn, we use our model to translate natural language problems into formal statements and back-translate to natural language problems collected from the math contest forum. We utilize the Lean compiler and Natural Language Inference (NLI) to verify if the formalization is valid. We sample invalid formalizations and require human experts to modify them into valid formalizations, adding them to the training set. Through the supplement of human-labeled data pairs, the translation model gradually learns to translate between Lean 4 formal language and natural language questions of different types of problems. We autoformalized 57K math problems in the final round, achieving an accuracy of 93.5% in a random sample of the Lean Workbook, as reported by manual examination. The same filtering process produces 21 new formal statements of the IMO questions that do not appear in Compfiles. In conclusion, our contribution can be summarized as follows:

• We propose an active learning pipeline for autoformalizing natural language questions.
• We open-source our translation model and pipeline, which can be used for autoformalizing diverse topics of math statements.
• We open-source a dataset containing 57k formalized math problems (5k of them have formal solutions) that can be used for autoformalization and auto theorem proving.
• We formalize 21 new IMO questions that have not appeared in Compfiles.

Our pipeline's performance is demonstrated through the derivation of high-quality formalized statements and the refinement of the translation model through active learning. By leveraging the iterative process, we can continually improve the model's performance and adapt it to new problem domains. The open-sourcing of our pipeline and dataset enables the community to utilize and build upon our work, contributing to the advancement of automatic theorem proving and math formalization.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Knowing the force of the resultant vector is the first part of the solution, which involves finding half the sum of the magnitudes of the two vectors. Finding the net angle of the resultant vector, which corresponds to half the difference between the angles of the two vectors, is the second part of the solution. This can be achieved by taking into account the individual angles of each vector, where the net angle is found by calculating the average of the two angles. To find the net angle, you can use the formula: net angle = (angle of vector 1 - angle of vector 2) / 2. Taking the example of a golfer hitting a golf ball into the air, we need to consider both the initial force of the hit, roughly equivalent to the force applied by a golfer's muscles, and the force of the wind, which can be thought of as an opposing force that changes the ball's trajectory, affecting its overall angle and speed. To find the resultant vector, we must first determine the individual components of the vectors. The horizontal and vertical component vectors represent the legs of a right triangle, where the resultant vector is the hypotenuse that can be calculated using the Pythagorean theorem, with its magnitude being the square root of the sum of the squares of the magnitudes of the horizontal and vertical component vectors. This is because the horizontal and vertical components form the two sides of the right triangle, and the resultant vector, being the hypotenuse, can be found using the theorem which states that in a right-angled triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides.

Addition is a simple concept when working with vectors, which represent movements, forces, or physical elements acting upon objects. When multiple forces act on an object, you can add them to find the resultant force. For example, consider a golf ball hit into the air. One force is the initial hit, with an angle and magnitude, while another force is the wind, also with an angle and magnitude.

To add vectors, you need to determine their components using trigonometry. For the golf ball hit at a 30-degree angle upward with 130 mph (210 km/h), the components are:

- Vertical: 65 mph (101.81 km/h)
- Horizontal: 112.6 mph (181.6 km/h)

Consider the wind's force, blowing downward at an angle of 10 degrees with 10 mph (16.1 km/h). The wind's components are:

- Vertical: -1.74 mph
- Horizontal: 9.85 mph

Since component vectors are measured at right angles, you can add them directly by matching horizontal components and vertical components. The resultant vertical vector is the sum of the two components: 63.26 mph (101.81 km/h) vertically and 122.45 miles per hour horizontally.

To find the net effect of both forces, you can put the components together using the Pythagorean theorem. This gives you the magnitude of the resultant vector: 137.83 mph (221.82 km/h).

Knowing the force of the resultant vector is half of the solution. The other half is to find the net angle of the resultant vector. To do this, sketch a right triangle with the horizontal base representing the forward vector component of 122.45 and the vertical leg representing the upward vector component of 63.26.

You can use the sine function to find the angle: sin⁡θ = 63.26/137.83 = 0.459, θ = arcsin(0.459) = 27.32 degrees.

Thus, the resultant vector represents a single force acting on the ball at an upward angle of 27.32 degrees. The resultant vector has a magnitude of 137.83 mph (221.82 km/h), at an angle of 27.32 degrees above the horizontal.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the refined text with a focus on fluency and a reduced number of sentences, while maintaining a minimum of 6 words per sentence:

Deep learning has demonstrated its significant learning capabilities in natural language processing (NLP). To deploy a natural language task, such as translation and text classification, researchers first pre-train a model to embed words into vectors using ELMo, GPT, and BERT. These pre-trained models are initially trained on a large unsupervised text corpus and then fine-tuned on different downstream tasks. As a result, they are referred to as large language models (LLMs) due to their relatively large number of model parameters.

Large LLMs have been deployed to learn program representations from source code. Similar to natural language, the program representation learned from source code using pre-trained models can be applied to several downstream program analysis tasks. In 2020, Feng et al. proposed a pre-trained model called CodeBERT, based on Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT), to learn general-purpose representations for downstream NL-PL applications.

In 2021, Guo et al. proposed a new pre-trained model, GraphCodeBERT, which improves CodeBERT by enabling the model to capture more program semantic information, such as data flow. Recently, researchers have adopted ChatGPT for various code analysis tasks, including code refinement and vulnerability discovery. In industry, GitHub Copilot, powered by GPT, assists developers by suggesting code snippets, completing functions, and providing contextual code recommendations directly within Integrated Development Environments.

However, the difference between natural language and programming language leads to unintended consequences when directly applying NLP models to programming language. In natural language, the meaning of a word is deterministic in a specific context, whereas in programming language, a programmer can assign any string to any variable, method, or function as their names. This results in most strings in the code not carrying meaningful information.

If a large language model heavily relies on the literal meaning of a variable, method, or function name, it may encounter problems when the assigned name does not contain useful information or has a controversial meaning. Therefore, it is doubtful whether the word embedding adopted in natural language is still efficient for solving program analysis tasks.

In this paper, we propose a taxonomy that groups features in programming languages into two categories: literal features and logical features. We aim to investigate how these different types of features affect the performance of current pre-trained models in downstream tasks and to what extent they influence the results. To achieve this goal, we create eight types of datasets that mask off different types of features to quantitatively measure their impact.

Our experiments with CodeBERT reveal the extent to which literal and logical features impact performance. While these models exhibit remarkable capabilities, their effectiveness can be influenced by unreliable features in the analyzed code. Instances such as code generated from decompilation or non-conventional code naming might yield reduced accuracy.

Additionally, since ChatGPT is a conversational large language model that can provide intuitive feedback, we conduct a case study to investigate the pre-trained model's ability to comprehend programming language in specific settings. Our results indicate that naming strategies have a significant impact on the performance of code analysis tasks based on LLMs, suggesting that code representation learning heavily relies on well-defined names in code.

llama3.polished_text:
Sign languages are a type of natural language that convey meaning through sequences of handshapes and gestures, as well as non-manual elements. They are a chief means of communication for approximately 70 million deaf people worldwide. Automatic sign language technologies would help bridge the communication barrier between deaf and hearing individuals, making deaf video media more searchable and indexable.

Sign language processing has gained significant interest in the computer vision and natural language processing communities in recent years. Yin et al. (2021) suggested several recommendations for sign language research in NLP, including a greater emphasis on real-world data. Most sign language studies are based on data collected in controlled environments, such as studio settings (Martínez et al., 2002; Kim et al., 2017) or specific domains (Forster et al., 2016).

However, the challenges involved in real-world signing videos, including various visual conditions and different levels of fluency, are not fully reflected in these datasets. Automatic processing of sign language videos in the wild has only recently been addressed and is still restricted to tasks like isolated sign recognition (Albanie et al., 2020; Joze and Koller, 2019; Li et al., 2020) and fingerspelling recognition (Shi et al., 2018, 2019).

In this work, we take a step further and study the search and retrieval of arbitrary fingerspelled content in real-world American Sign Language (ASL) video. Specifically, we focus on two search tasks: word search (FWS) for determining which words are fingerspelled in a sign language video clip, and fingerspelling video search (FVS) for searching for sign language videos that include a fingerspelled query word or phrase.

The sign language videos used in our study are untrimmed, meaning they include regular signs in addition to fingerspelling, and are downsampled for visualization. Fingerspelling is a component of sign language where words are signed by a series of handshapes or movements corresponding to single letters (see the Appendix for the ASL fingerspelling alphabet). Fingerspelling is used mainly for lexical items that do not have their own signs, such as proper nouns or technical terms, and has an important place in sign language.

For example, fingerspelling accounts for 12-35% of ASL (Padden and Gunsauls, 2003). Since important content like named entities is often fingerspelled, the fingerspelled portions of a sign language video often carry a disproportionate amount of the content. Most prior work on fingerspelling has focused on recognition, that is, transcription of a fingerspelling video clip into text.

However, automatic recognition assumes that the boundaries of fingerspelled segments are known at test time, and may not be the end goal in real-world use cases. In addition, complete transcription may not be necessary to extract the needed information. Fingerspelling search, such as retrieving sign language videos based on a query word, is a more practical task, and is an important component of general video search involving sign language.

In addition to introducing the task, we address the research question of whether the explicit temporal localization of fingerspelling can help its search and retrieval, and how best to localize it. As fingerspelling occurs sparsely in the signing stream, explicit detection of fingerspelling could potentially improve search performance by removing unrelated signs.

To this end, we propose an end-to-end model, FSS-Net, which jointly detects fingerspelling from unconstrained signing video and matches it to text queries. Our approach consistently outperforms a series of baselines without explicit detection and a baseline with an off-the-shelf fingerspelling detector by a large margin.

The proposed FSS-Net model consists of a CNN-based fingerspelling detector and a text encoder. The fingerspelling detector is trained to detect fingerspelling from unconstrained signing video, and the text encoder is trained to encode text queries into a compact vector representation. The two components are jointly trained to optimize the search and retrieval performance.

We evaluate the proposed FSS-Net model on a real-world ASL video dataset, and demonstrate its effectiveness in search and retrieval tasks. Our results show that the explicit temporal localization of fingerspelling can significantly improve search performance, and that the proposed FSS-Net model can achieve state-of-the-art performance in searching and retrieving sign language videos based on fingerspelled content.

In conclusion, this work presents a novel approach to searching and retrieving sign language videos based on fingerspelled content, and demonstrates its effectiveness in real-world scenarios. The proposed FSS-Net model can be a valuable tool for deaf and hard-of-hearing individuals, and can facilitate more inclusive and accessible communication in sign language communities.

Future work can focus on improving the robustness of the proposed model to various visual conditions and noise, as well as exploring other sign language processing tasks, such as sign language translation and captioning. Additionally, the proposed model can be extended to other languages and modalities, such as spoken language and lip reading.

Overall, this work contributes to the growing research in sign language processing and provides a new direction for developing more effective and efficient methods for searching and retrieving sign language videos based on fingerspelled content.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the revised text, condensed to fewer than 21 sentences, without altering the 13th sentence:

Accessing structured information through natural language interfaces has garnered significant research interest in natural language processing (NLP). The emerging information retrieval paradigm of conversational search frames information-seeking processes within multiturn dialogue interactions. This paradigm, conversational search, facilitates exploring and progressively narrowing the search scope to relevant knowledge items within an information space. These search-oriented conversational interfaces are often connected to structured data sources like knowledge graphs. However, mediating between natural language, in which users express their queries, and machine-readable knowledge representations is a key challenge.

The task of data-to-text generation focuses on this issue, taking structured data as input to produce coherent, human-readable text. This task has been extensively studied with approaches ranging from rule-based to supervised neural network-based techniques. The field of NLP has witnessed a shift in methodologies with the advent of pre-trained large language models (LLMs). Unlike traditional supervised learning approaches, LLMs are trained in a self-supervised manner, predicting tokens within vast amounts of unlabeled data.

LLMs offer tremendous potential for conversational interaction, but they have known limitations, such as the risk of hallucinating or omitting important information and a lack of transparency regarding the origins of information sources. In order to mitigate these limitations, it becomes imperative to ground their generated outputs in verifiable factual data from knowledge graphs. However, there has been insufficient systematic investigation into their efficiency in verbalizing graph-structured data input.

To assess LLMs in knowledge-based text generation, we compare four models of different sizes and training objectives, with a primary focus on models optimized for conversational interaction. We evaluate the models' performance in generating natural language text from semantic triples using the WebNLG benchmark dataset. Our contributions include adapting the WebNLG benchmark to evaluate closed- and open-source LLMs, providing a thorough error analysis, and creating a new fine-tuning dataset with 26,422 conversations with triple-to-text verbalizations. We publish our source code and datasets in a GitHub repository to ensure reproducibility.

To have a successful conversation with your parents, it's essential to know exactly what you want to happen beforehand. This clarity of purpose will enable you to remain focused and avoid getting sidetracked by unnecessary debate. Do you want to go to a dance, enjoy a later curfew, or plan a special dinner with your parents? Take the time to think about what you're hoping to achieve from the conversation, and it may be beneficial to write down the key points. By having a clear understanding of what you want, you'll be better prepared to address any questions or concerns your parents may raise. Having all the necessary details at your fingertips will also help you respond to their queries confidently. In fact, having a well-prepared and organized approach will help calm your parents down and make them more receptive to your requests. For instance, if you want to spend the night at a friend's house, make sure you have all the essential information, such as her parents' contact details, the planned start time, what you need to bring, and when your parents can pick you up. Having this information readily available will make it easier to answer any questions your parents may have and alleviate their concerns.

It's also a good idea to choose a time when your parents are not busy or distracted, as this will give you their full attention and enable you to have a more productive conversation. If you're unsure about the best time to approach them, simply ask your parents when they would be available to discuss the matter. Don't try to drag out the conversation or prolong it unnecessarily, as this will only serve to increase your nervousness and make the situation more uncomfortable.

Once you've got your parents' attention, start by stating your intention and expressing your hope that they will keep an open mind. For example, you could begin by saying, "I'd like to discuss something with you, and I'd appreciate it if you could listen carefully to what I have to say." If you find it difficult to get the conversation started, it's perfectly fine to begin with a more casual topic, as long as you eventually get to the point. A good way to persuade someone to do something is to highlight the benefits it will bring to them, so think about how your parents will benefit from what you're asking for and try to emphasize that aspect.

For example, if you're trying to convince your parents to let you go out for a night, you could point out that they'll have the house all to themselves. Alternatively, if you're trying to persuade them to eat out at a particular restaurant, you could mention their favorite dishes. However, be honest and truthful in your approach, as trying to lie or deceive your parents will only serve to damage your relationship with them in the long run. They know you well and can likely tell when you're not telling the truth, so it's essential to stick to the facts and express your feelings in a clear and respectful manner.

When expressing your feelings or concerns, try to use "I" statements instead of "you" statements, which can come across as accusatory or confrontational. For instance, say, "I feel upset when I can't go out with my friends" rather than "You're awful for not letting me go out with my friends." The former statement simply expresses your feelings, while the latter puts your parents on the defensive.

Having details and evidence to back up your claims can also be helpful in persuading your parents. For example, if you're trying to convince them to let you join the school band, you could provide research articles that demonstrate the benefits of music education. You could say, "As this research shows, being in the band can help me improve my math skills. I'd be happy to let you read through the relevant pages." 

If you're trying to get your parents to do something they don't want to do, it may be helpful to hear their perspective and understand their concerns. They may have good points that you hadn't considered, and by listening to their views, you may be able to find a mutually beneficial solution.

The line we stood in felt like a mile long, and we were definitely waiting for around an hour to an hour and a half to get inside, but that was the only line for the weekend, so it wasn't too bad. Once we were inside, the culture was always great – just tons of love for video games and people, and just everyone looking around, having a good time, buying things, and relaxing. The AirBnB was also great, as we all just got to relax in a nice house in the suburbs, play games, and talk. A friend of mine had bought a card game that doubled as a drinking game, so we played that. It was a lot of fun – everyone just sharing things, laughing, and overall just getting pretty drunk.

When everyone had decided they had had enough that night, we called it quits and slept. The next day, I woke up and wondered where everyone was, and found a friend of mine awake. He figured they had already gone to the convention center, so he and I walked to a Denny's for breakfast. The meal was good and fun, and from there, we met everyone at the convention center. It was a great full day of hanging out, exploring, listening to panels, and then we headed back home for the night. We found out it was my friend's birthday that weekend, so we got him a cake and sang for him that night. The next day was our last day in Dallas, so we decided to just hang out again, have some great food, and visit spots around the city. We were dreading the long drive home, but at the same time looking forward to the stop at Buc-ees again. Getting home, everyone was happy to relax and get some rest, but at the same time, sad that the weekend had ended so quickly. Either way, it was a great time, and we all look forward to next year.
