trips_llama3.polished_text: Natural language processing (NLP) is witnessing explosive growth in applications and public visibility, with large language models being deployed in many real-life applications, including general-purpose chatbots and the generation of medical reports (Min et al. al., 2023). However, widespread use of these models raises concerns about frequent hallucinations (Ji et al., 2023), poor model calibration (Vasudevan et al., 2019), limited and sometimes contaminated evaluation (Sainz et al., 2023), unreliable explanations (Zhao et al., 2024), and model biases (Gallegos et al., 2024). To address these concerns, NLP systems should provide accurate answers and convey uncertainty when appropriate, ensuring transparency and trustworthiness in their output. Uncertainty quantification systems are rare and limited due to incorrect assumptions, poor calibration, and a lack of robustness and versatility, which can be attributed to the complexity and diversity of NLP tasks (Kuleshov et al., 2018). CP methods are model-agnostic, distribution-free, and assume data exchangeability, making them highly versatile, but their flexibility and adaptability also rely on their non-parametric nature and ability to handle various types of data, as well as their capacity to leverage the strengths of deep learning and machine learning techniques, and their ability to provide a more accurate and nuanced representation of uncertainty. In this context, CP methods offer a reliable approach to uncertainty quantification, providing a transparent way to quantify uncertainty in complex systems. We will provide a comprehensive overview of the CP framework, its extensions, and direct applications in NLP, review the existing literature and current issues, and explore potential avenues of future research, highlighting the benefits and advantages of CP in NLP, and discussing its potential applications in areas such as natural language understanding, text generation, and sentiment analysis, and providing a detailed analysis of its strengths and limitations.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the improved text, keeping the term 'al.' unchanged and ensuring the output has fewer than 23 sentences:

Natural language processing (NLP) has witnessed explosive growth in applications and public visibility, driven by large language models (LLMs) being deployed in various real-life applications, such as general-purpose chatbots and medical report generation (Min et al., 2023). However, the widespread use of these models raises concerns: hallucinations are frequent (Ji et al., 2023; Guerreiro et al., 2023), models are poorly calibrated (Vasudevan et al., 2019; Desai and Durrett, 2020), and evaluation is limited and sometimes affected by data contamination (Sainz et al., 2023; Golchin and Surdeanu, 2024). Reliable uncertainty quantification is crucial to addressing these concerns. Unfortunately, most NLP systems return single predictions without reliable confidence information.

Conformal prediction (CP) has emerged as a promising candidate to bypass these issues. This method offers statistical guarantees of ground-truth coverage with minimal assumptions and is model-agnostic and distribution-free. CP methods assume only data exchangeability and are efficient, not requiring model retraining and allowing for online or offline use with a relatively small calibration set.

Extensions of CP that handle non-exchangeable data have been proposed (Gibbs and Candes, 2021; Barber et al., 2023). Equalized variants of CP can also reduce biases and unfairness by distributing coverage evenly across protected attributes (Romano et al., 2020). The flexibility and strong statistical guarantees of CP have attracted considerable interest, with an increasing number of publications in computer science.

This survey provides a comprehensive overview of CP techniques for NLP tasks. After briefly explaining CP and some relevant extensions, we review direct applications thereof in NLP and look at possible threads of future investigation and current open issues. This survey is not a general survey on uncertainty quantification and does not include techniques not based on CP. Comprehensive reviews of uncertainty quantification in NLP were recently published (2023) and Hu et al. (2023).

Stuff the tail with cotton stuffing and place a flexible wire in the center if you would like to be able to adjust the shape of the tail. Sew the top together and sew an additional loop to the top to thread a belt through.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Everyone has neighbors who are noisy from time to time, and we are generally able to accommodate for this with no difficulty. However, you may have something big coming up such as a job interview or a change in work schedule, and are worried that your neighbor's noise may become a problem for you. If this is the case, it's better to be proactive and let your neighbors know ahead of time that you'll need more quiet than usual. For example, in the days before your important event or schedule change, stop by your neighbor's with a plate of homemade cookies and explain your situation to them: “Hey Sam, I've got final exams all next week, and will need extra quiet time. Would you mind rescheduling your band's practice on those days, or maybe even temporarily moving it to a different location? It would help so much.” Talking directly to your neighbors is probably the most mature strategy, and is often the most effective, particularly if you are able to connect with them personally and get them to sympathize with your predicament. If you're not familiar with your neighbors, then leaving them a very politely worded note in their mailbox or on their door could be an effective way to alert them to the problem, especially if your schedules don't align with your schedule to interact with them outside of their home. Leaving them a note in their mailbox or on their door allows you to bring the issue to their attention in a clear and polite manner. You can include specific details about the problem, such as the time of day and the noise level. Be sure to explain that you can hear their television at 11pm when you are trying to get to sleep, and note that it is loud enough that you can hear all of the dialogue on the program. Be sure to suggest a specific solution in your note, such as reducing the volume by one-third or moving the television to the opposite side of the room, away from your shared wall. If the situation remains unresolved, you should keep a dated copy of the note for your records. Keep in mind that just because you can hear your neighbors, it doesn't automatically mean that they are being too noisy and that you would be justified in asking them to quiet down. Remember that people do have the right to make noise in their own home. Of course, what one person finds mildly annoying the next someone else might find unbearable—these are somewhat subjective terms. Consider whether their noise is significantly disrupting your ability to sleep, work, or enjoy your own activities. If that's the case, then a conversation probably is called for. If, on the other hand, your only complaint is that you can hear their kids playing in the middle of the afternoon while you are trying to read your novel, your request to ask them to keep the noise down may come across as being overly antagonistic. In that case, you might consider finding an alternative solution, such as moving to a different room or using earplugs, to minimize the disturbance.

**Refining Hair Bleaching and Toning Process**

To achieve the desired results when bleaching and toning your hair, it's essential to follow a well-planned and carefully executed process. In this comprehensive guide, we'll walk you through each step, providing you with the tools and knowledge needed to achieve your desired hair color.

**Preparation is Key**

Before you begin the bleaching and toning process, make sure you have the necessary materials and follow these essential steps:

1.  **Cover your work surface**: Protect your counter and floor with newspaper or plastic bags to prevent any potential stains or messes.
2.  **Dress for the task**: Wear an old shirt or drape an old towel over your shoulders to prevent any accidental bleach stains.
3.  **Apply petroleum jelly**: Coat your hairline and ear tips with petroleum jelly to prevent any irritation or damage.
4.  **Don protective gloves**: Put on a pair of plastic dyeing gloves to prevent any skin irritation or allergic reactions.

**Hair Preparation**

Before applying bleach, ensure that your hair is in the best possible condition. To achieve the best results, follow these steps:

1.  **Deep condition your hair**: Deep condition your hair the night before you plan to bleach it to ensure it's healthy and ready for the process.
2.  **Choose the right bleach kit**: Purchase a good-quality hair bleaching kit that contains bleach and developer.
3.  **Select the right developer**: Based on your hair color, choose the correct developer volume: 10 volume for light brown hair, 20 volume for medium brown hair, or 30 volume for dark brown or black hair (use with caution).

**Applying the Bleach**

To apply the bleach correctly, follow these steps:

1.  **Prepare the bleach**: Mix the bleach in a non-metal bowl according to the kit's instructions.
2.  **Section your hair**: Divide your hair into 4 sections (optional) to make the process easier.
3.  **Apply the bleach**: Use a tinting brush to apply the bleach to your hair, starting from the ends and mid-lengths first, then work your way up to the roots. Never apply bleach to the roots first, as this can cause it to process too fast and damage your hair.
4.  **Monitor the processing time**: Check your hair every 5 minutes, and once it reaches a pale blond color, rinse it out.

**Processing Time and Safety Precautions**

The processing time will depend on the initial color of your hair and the volume developer you're using. To avoid damaging your hair, be sure to:

1.  **Check your hair regularly**: Monitor the processing time and rinse the bleach out after 30 to 45 minutes, or once your hair reaches a pale blond color.
2.  **Avoid over-processing**: Never leave bleach in your hair for longer than 45 minutes, as this can cause irreparable damage.
3.  **Be aware of individual differences**: Everyone's hair reacts differently to bleach, so be patient and adjust the processing time accordingly.

**Rinsing and Conditioning**

After rinsing out the bleach, follow these steps:

1.  **Rinse with cool water**: Rinse the bleach out with cool water to prevent any further damage.
2.  **Apply shampoo**: Apply some shampoo to your hair and lather it up, then rinse the shampoo out.
3.  **Condition your hair (optional)**: If you want to, you can apply a deep-conditioning mask or a hair toner, but it's best to wait until after the toning process.

**Toning Your Hair**

If your hair has brassy tones or you want to achieve a specific shade, use a hair toner or purple toning shampoo. Follow the instructions on the bottle, and be sure to:

1.  **Read the instructions**: Understand the product's instructions, including any mixing requirements or recommended developer volumes.
2.  **Apply the toner**: Apply the toner according to the instructions, and be sure to leave it in your hair for the recommended time (usually 20 to 30 minutes).
3.  **Rinse and condition**: Rinse the toner out and apply a deep-conditioning mask to moisturize and nourish your hair.

**Final Touches**

After toning your hair, follow these final steps:

1.  **Deep condition your hair**: Apply a deep-conditioning mask to your hair, focusing on damaged, dry, or color-treated areas.
2.  **Leave it on**: Leave the deep-conditioning mask on for the recommended time (usually 5 to 15 minutes).
3.  **Rinse and style**: Rinse the deep-conditioning mask out and style your hair as usual.

By following this comprehensive guide, you'll be able to achieve the desired results and achieve the perfect hair color. Remember to be patient, follow the instructions carefully, and take necessary safety precautions to avoid damaging your hair.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Objectives and goals have distinct differences, which should be understood before attempting to write an objective. Goals are broad and often difficult to measure, focusing on big picture issues. In a college class on child psychology, a goal might be to help students appreciate the need for clinical training when dealing with small children. While such a goal would inform more specific educational objectives, it is not specific enough to be an objective itself. Educational objectives are much more specific and include measurable verbs and criteria for acceptable performance regarding a particular subject. For example, the educational objective is to identify three theorists whose work on child psychology influenced teaching practices in the US by the end of this unit. This educational objective is specific, as it includes measurable verbs and criteria for acceptable performance based on the educational framework. In 1956, Benjamin Bloom created a framework to classify different types of learning and illustrate different levels of learning. Bloom's Taxonomy is commonly used as a framework when writing educational objectives, providing guidelines for creating specific learning objectives. Bloom identified three domains of learning, with the cognitive domain receiving the most focus in higher education. The cognitive domain focuses on intellectual, scholarly learning and consists of six levels. The first level is knowledge, which includes memorizing and recalling previously learned materials. This includes memorizing multiplication tables and recalling historical events. The second level is comprehension, which involves demonstrating understanding by organizing, interpreting, or comparing facts. An example is translating a Japanese sentence into German. The third level is application, which means solving problems by applying knowledge to various situations. An example is using pi to solve mathematical problems. The fourth level is analysis, which involves reexamining facts to understand why they are true. An example is understanding the concept of "fate" as a predetermined destiny. The fifth level is synthesis, where students organize information in new ways to discover new patterns or alternative ideas. At this level, students create a painting, among other activities. The sixth level is evaluation, which involves presenting and defending information and making informed judgments about others' opinions. An example is creating a short film humanizing immigrants in your community with commentary on why they deserve respect. When writing an educational objective, focus on three key characteristics: performance, condition, and criterion. These characteristics help you effectively communicate your class's intent and teaching style. An educational objective should specify what students are expected to do by the end of a unit or class. A good educational objective outlines the conditions under which a student is supposed to perform a task. A good educational objective outlines the expectations that need to be met for a student's performance to be considered passing. A good educational objective in a nursing class might be to draw blood in a typical hospital setting within a 2 to 3 minute timeframe.

llama3.polished_text:
Malaria is a life-threatening infection caused by Plasmodium parasites, primarily spread through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. One of the primary symptoms of a malarial infection is a high fever, typically above 102°F (38.9°C), which can appear as early as seven days, but usually between 10 – 15 days, after being bitten by an infected mosquito. This fever often comes and goes randomly, a characteristic believed to be related to the malaria parasites transiently spreading into the bloodstream from the liver.

At least five types of Plasmodium parasites can infect humans, with P. falciparum and P. vivax being the most common and deadly, mainly affecting populations in Africa and Latin America, respectively. The initial symptoms of malaria may be mild and resemble those of less serious viral infections, such as the common cold and influenza, often leading individuals to delay seeking medical attention. Symptoms usually don't appear for about two weeks after being bitten by an infected mosquito.

In addition to fever, the other primary symptom of malaria is severe shaking chills with intermittent periods of sweating, which can be mistaken for seizures when severe. Shaking chills can cause teeth to chatter and even prevent sleep, and are not typically relieved by blanket cover or warmer clothing. This symptom can be more pronounced and severe in malaria compared to other infections.

Malarial symptoms can appear within a few weeks of being bitten by an infected mosquito, but some types of parasites can remain dormant in the body for up to a year or more. The parasites cause symptoms by migrating to the liver, where they lay dormant for a week or two before entering the bloodstream and proliferating in the body.

Secondary and less specific symptoms of malaria include moderate-to-severe headaches, often accompanied by mild muscle aches, which can occur a short while after the primary symptoms as the parasite needs more time to proliferate in the liver and spread throughout the body. Headaches and muscle aches are common in many other infections, as well as from the bites of other insects and spiders.

The bites from female Anopheles mosquitoes are not very noticeable, unlike those of some other insects and spiders that can cause similar symptoms. Initial headaches in malaria are typically dull, similar to a tension headache, but can become pounding, like a migraine, as the parasites infect and destroy red blood cells.

Other non-specific secondary symptoms of malaria include vomiting and diarrhea, which can occur multiple times per day and often in combination with each other, mimicking the initial symptoms of food poisoning and other bacterial infections. However, the main difference is that the vomiting and diarrhea caused by food poisoning usually resolves within a few days, whereas it can persist for weeks with malaria, depending on treatment.

Unlike the explosive and bloody diarrhea of some bacterial infections, such as Shigella, the diarrhea caused by malaria is usually not bloody or accompanied by severe cramping. Once the primary and secondary symptoms become noticeable, the malaria-causing parasites can be seen under a microscope from a drop of infected blood, especially if stained with Giemsa stain.

If the advancing primary and secondary symptoms don't prompt the infected person to seek medical attention and receive treatment, symptoms can progress to indicate serious injury or damage to the body. Confusion, multiple convulsions, coma, and neurological impairment can indicate brain swelling and injury. Severe anemia, abnormal bleeding, deep labored breathing, and respiratory distress can indicate advanced blood infection and lung involvement. Jaundice, or yellowish skin and eyes, can be evidence of liver damage and dysfunction.

In severe cases, malaria can cause kidney failure, liver failure, shock (very low blood pressure), and an enlarged spleen. It's essential to seek medical attention promptly if symptoms of malaria appear, as the risk of health complications and death significantly increases when advanced symptoms develop.

Malaria remains a significant public health concern in many parts of the world, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions. Early detection and treatment are crucial in preventing the progression of malaria to severe stages, which can be life-threatening. Medical professionals recommend prompt medical attention if symptoms of malaria appear, as timely treatment can significantly improve outcomes.

The risk of malaria is highest in areas with high mosquito populations and inadequate access to healthcare. In these regions, the parasite can spread rapidly, leading to outbreaks and widespread illness. The World Health Organization (WHO) and other global health authorities recommend measures to prevent malaria, including the use of insecticide-treated bed nets, indoor residual spraying, and antimalarial medications.

Prevention and early detection are key to controlling malaria outbreaks. Individuals traveling to areas with high malaria transmission risk should take preventive measures, such as using insecticide-treated bed nets and antimalarial medications, and seek medical attention immediately if symptoms appear. By taking these precautions and seeking prompt medical attention, individuals can reduce their risk of contracting malaria and prevent its progression to severe stages.

In areas with high malaria transmission risk, public health campaigns can help raise awareness about the disease, its symptoms, and the importance of seeking medical attention promptly. By educating the public and healthcare professionals about malaria, we can reduce its impact and save lives.

llama3.polished_text:
You may be processing many different emotions when considering coming out to your mom. Writing out your thoughts and feelings can help you organize them before the conversation. To prepare, try answering the following questions:

- How comfortable are you with your sexuality?
- Do you feel secure with your bisexuality or are you still questioning it?
- Do you think your mom can help support you emotionally?
- How do you feel about coming out to your mom?
- Are you scared, anxious, or worried about her reaction?

Consider your mom's feelings and potential reaction. Think about her beliefs towards bisexual people. Ask yourself:

- Does she agree with bisexuality?
- Will she be accepting or angry about you coming out?
- Is she familiar with what bisexuality is?
- Will she be confused by your coming out?

If you live far away from your mom, consider a phone or video call to make the conversation more personal. Choose a quiet time, like just before or after dinner. If you're worried about her reaction, writing a letter or email can be a helpful alternative. Try to meet her in person if possible.

Before having the talk, practice with a friend or by talking to yourself in a mirror. Rehearse starting the conversation and what you want to say. If you're writing a letter, ask someone to read over it and provide feedback.

There are many LGBT groups that offer mental and emotional support as you prepare to tell your parents. These organizations can provide you with valuable resources and stories from others who have come out.

Remember, you can't predict your mom's exact reaction, but you can mentally prepare for different outcomes. Bisexuality is valid and common, and you can be a successful and valued member of society regardless of your mom's reaction.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Bilingual data, including bilingual sentences and terms, are critical resources for building various applications, such as machine translation and cross-language information retrieval. However, most existing bilingual data sets are inadequate for their intended uses, not up-to-date, and apply only to limited domains. Because it is very hard and expensive to create a large-scale bilingual dataset with human effort, many researchers have turned to automatically mining them from the web. If a web page contains content in two languages, we call it a bilingual web page. Many such pages exist on non-English websites, typically with a primary language and a secondary language, often English. The content in the secondary language is often the translation of some primary language text in the page. Since bilingual web pages are common on non-English websites, mining bilingual data from them should be an important task. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no publication available on mining bilingual sentences directly from bilingual web pages. Most existing methods for mining bilingual sentences from the web, such as those proposed by Nie et al. in 1999, Resnik and Smith in 2003, and Shi et al. in 2006, try to mine parallel web documents first and then extract bilingual sentences using sentence alignment methods. Additionally, Cao et al. in 2007 and Lin et al. in 2008 proposed methods to extract term translations based on observed patterns in bilingual web pages. Another interesting phenomenon is that bilingual data often appear collectively and follow similar surface patterns. For example, Figure 1 shows an excerpt of a page listing dog names in both English and Chinese, following a consistent format. Similarly, there are also many pages containing consistently formatted bilingual sentences. These pages, such as online stores listing their products in two languages, are created for various reasons, including facilitating foreign language learning. In some pages, authors provide translations for disambiguation. We will call pages containing many consistently formatted translation pairs collective bilingual pages, of which tens of millions exist in Chinese web sites. Most importantly, each collective bilingual page usually contains a large amount of bilingual data, showing the great potential of bilingual data mining. However, the mining task is not straightforward due to varying patterns in different pages. Another challenge is that some pages contain consistently formatted texts in two languages, but they are not translation pairs. Furthermore, not all translations follow an exactly consistent format. Therefore, we propose a pattern-based approach that involves learning patterns adaptively from collective bilingual pages. Our approach contains four steps. First, we preprocess the web page into a DOM tree and segment the inner text into snippets. Second, we identify potential translation pairs using an alignment model. Third, we learn generalized patterns with the identified seeds. Finally, we extract all bilingual data using the learned patterns. For example, our method identifies "Boxer 拳师" as a potential translation pair. Then, we learn a generalized pattern that both pairs follow. Finally, we apply it to match the entire text and get all translation pairs following the pattern. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we list some related work. In Section 4, we give a detailed introduction to each of the four modules in our mining approach.

Bilingual data, including bilingual sentences and bilingual terms, are critical resources for building various applications, such as machine translation (Brown, 1993) and cross-language information retrieval (Nie et al., 1999). However, most existing bilingual data sets are inadequate for their intended uses, outdated, and limited to specific domains. Creating large-scale bilingual datasets with human effort is challenging and expensive. Therefore, many researchers have turned to automatically mining bilingual data from the web.

A Bilingual Web Page is a web page containing content written in two languages. These pages are common in non-English websites, often with a primary language (usually a non-English language) and a secondary language (usually English). The content in the secondary language is typically the translation of primary language text within the page.

Given the prevalence of bilingual web pages in non-English websites, mining bilingual data from them is an essential task. However, to date, there is no publication available on directly mining bilingual sentences from bilingual web pages. Most existing methods for mining bilingual sentences from the web, such as Nie et al. (1999), Resnik, and Smith (2003), and Shi et al. (2006), attempt to mine parallel web documents within bilingual websites first and then extract bilingual sentences from the mined parallel documents using sentence alignment methods.

Regarding mining term translations from bilingual web pages, Cao et al. (2007) and Lin et al. (2008) proposed two different methods to extract term translations based on the observation that authors of many bilingual web pages, particularly those with primary languages such as Chinese, Japanese, or Korean, sometimes annotate terms with their English translations inside a pair of parentheses, like “c1c2...cn(e1 e2...em)” (c1c2...cn is a primary language term and e1 e2...em is its English translation). Moreover, in addition to the parenthesis pattern, another interesting phenomenon is that many bilingual web pages exhibit bilingual data that appear collectively and follow similar surface patterns. For instance, Figure 1 shows an excerpt of a page that introduces different kinds of dogs, providing a list of dog names in both English and Chinese. The bilingual names on this page do not follow the parenthesis pattern but are identically formatted as: “{Number}。{English name}{Chinese name}{EndOfLine}”. One exceptional pair (“1.Alaskan Malamute 啊拉斯加雪橇犬”) differs only slightly. Furthermore, there are also many pages containing consistently formatted bilingual sentences (see Figure 2). The page lists the (claimed) 200 most common oral sentences in English and their Chinese translations to facilitate English learning.

People create such web pages for various reasons. Some online stores list their products in two languages to make them understandable to foreigners. Some pages aim to help readers with foreign language learning. In addition, in some pages where foreign names or technical terms are mentioned, the authors provide the translations for disambiguation. For easy reference, we will call pages containing many consistently formatted translation pairs Collective Bilingual Pages.

According to our estimation, tens of millions of collective bilingual pages exist in Chinese websites. Most importantly, each such page usually contains a large amount of bilingual data, showcasing the great potential of bilingual data mining. However, the mining task is not straightforward due to the following reasons:

1.  The patterns vary in different pages, making it impossible to mine the translation pairs using predefined templates.
2.  Some pages contain consistently formatted texts in two languages, but they are not translation pairs.
3.  Not all translations in a collective bilingual page necessarily follow an exactly consistent format. As shown in Figure 1, the ten translation pairs are supposed to follow the same pattern, however, due to typos, the pattern of the first pair is slightly different.

Because of these difficulties, simply using a classifier to extract translation pairs from adjacent bilingual texts in a collective bilingual page may not achieve satisfactory results. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a pattern-based approach: learning patterns adaptively from collective bilingual pages instead of using the parenthesis pattern, then using the learned patterns to extract translation pairs from corresponding web pages. Our approach contains four steps:

1.  **Preprocessing**: Parse the web page into a DOM tree and segment the inner text of each node into snippets.
2.  **Seed mining**: Identify potential translation pairs (seeds) using an alignment model that takes both translation and transliteration into consideration.
3.  **Pattern learning**: Learn generalized patterns with the identified seeds.
4.  **Pattern-based mining**: Extract all bilingual data in the page using the learned patterns.

Let us take mining bilingual data from the text shown in Figure 1 as an example. Our method identifies “Boxer 拳师” and “Eskimo Dog 爱斯基摩犬” as two potential translation pairs based on a dictionary and a transliteration model (Step 2 above). Then, we learn a generalized pattern that both pairs follow as “{BulletNumber}{Punctuation}{English term}{Chinese term}{EndOfLine}”, (Step 3 above). Finally, we apply it to match in the entire text and get all translation pairs following the pattern (Step 4 above).

llama3.polished_text:
The current discussion on the relationship between large language models (LLMs) and knowledge graphs (KGs) remains highly active and multifaceted. Whether these two entities can effectively complement each other, how LLMs and KGs can be seamlessly integrated, and the question of whether future research should focus on KG assisting LLMs or vice versa continue to remain unanswered. To advance research on the amalgamation of knowledge graphs and large language models, we initiated the TechGPT-1.0 and TechGPT-2.0 projects, a pioneering endeavor that aimed to bridge the knowledge gap between these two technologies. These projects encompassed the release of three 7B-scale instruction fine-tuning models and a QLoRA model tailored for long texts, showcasing our commitment to innovation and excellence in the field. The extensive models developed within the TechGPT-1.0 and TechGPT-2.0 projects concentrated primarily on diverse subtasks related to constructing knowledge graphs, including tasks like named entity recognition (NER) and reading comprehension (RTE), which are crucial for empowering large language models with knowledge graph capabilities.

Furthermore, we will provide comprehensive insights into data collection and processing, share experiences in debugging the Ascend server, and delineate our model training procedures, aiming to serve as a valuable reference and support for researchers seeking to train large-scale language models on the Ascend server. Specifically, experienced researchers in our research group curated batches of knowledge graphs to construct datasets for subtasks such as NER and RTE, which were subsequently modified to align with instructions and fine-tune the data format. Notably, the knowledge graph employed for constructing the subtask dataset encompasses open-source data collected from public datasets, alongside research data accumulated in previous projects of our research group.

This data underwent collation and manual annotation by our group's researchers to ensure its accuracy and relevance. To ensure the sustained general ability of the large language model during the complete fine-tuning process, we adhered to conclusions drawn from prior experiments, which emphasized the importance of balancing general instruction fine-tuning data with knowledge graph domain data. A substantial volume of general instruction fine-tuning data was compiled, and this was amalgamated with knowledge graph domain data in appropriate proportions, resulting in an approximate 4 million instances of instruction fine-tuning data. Additionally, significant disparities exist between the model training process on the Ascend server and traditional NVIDIA graphics cards, which necessitates a deeper understanding of the unique challenges and practices related to model training on the Ascend server.

Our intention is to share insights into the unique challenges and practices related to model training on the Ascend server, offering valuable guidance for researchers contemplating exploration on this platform in the future. Owing to limitations in our server resources, detailed experiments on the models within the TechGPT-1.0 and TechGPT-2.0 projects were not pursued, and consequently, this report provides only concise summaries of straightforward experimental outcomes. For a more in-depth exploration of model performance, we encourage you to visit open-source communities like HuggingFace, ModelScope, and WiseModel for downloads and firsthand experiences. Alternatively, you may explore the detailed experiences available on the experience page shared by our research team.

trips_llama3.polished_text: On May 20th, 2019, my girlfriend, my friend, and I drove to and around Joshua Tree National Park to film different wild animals like rattlesnakes, coyotes, and owls. We had spent about five hours in the late afternoon looking before it got dark and we decided to head home. We were driving through a town next to the park called 29 Palms that has a marine base in it when we saw a UFO from the car! It was a long, bright light in the sky that was out in the desert. We pulled over and started to film the object and talk about what it was. It didn't seem to move much in the air and didn't seem far away. My girlfriend was driving and figured we might be able to get closer to it (we were about a mile away) so we drove down some streets to get to it. We were able to drive right up to it and film it for about 25 minutes. The light looked like a long, glowing ribbon in the sky that made no noise. It was very windy but was able to control itself against the wind and would lift up into the sky a few hundred feet and come back down less than one hundred feet above our heads. Many other people started to stop and see the UFO. After close to 30 minutes since we originally saw the object, it started to move away from us, against the wind, making us get back in our cars and drive another street over to it. As we pulled up, we saw the item come down to the ground and turn off. Myself, my friend, and 9 other people that stopped to see the UFO all ran out of our cars and into the desert to look for it, but we couldn't find it at all. We couldn't figure out where it went or what it was. The most likely explanation was it was a light-up tail of a kite or a rope on a drone, but it made no noise, so drone is out; if it's a kite, where was the guy holding it? They had to have seen all these people stopped on the side of the road looking and running into the desert to find it. There are some powerlines that cross between where we stood under the object and where it came down, so that's not safe, and how did it not get stuck? I have tried looking for the object online but can't find anyone selling anything similar to it, and the videos online do not look like my video or the object we saw. On the drive home, I uploaded the video I took of the UFO; now, most of my videos are of animals, so this one was a little out of place, but by morning, had thousands of people emailing, messaging, commenting on the video asking questions trying to figure it out. A number of large UFO and paranormal YouTubers reached out to me to use the footage on their shows and podcasts. It was really cool and a lot of fun, and I was asked to be interviewed for a show on the Travel Channel, which I did, and was also a lot of fun.

Large language models (LLMs) have been the most significant technological advance in recent years. They interact through natural language, making it easy to capture people's attention and imagination. However, this also makes it easy for people to draw conclusions or opinions about LLMs without proper understanding.

When we interact through a text chat, we read responses to our questions. LLMs are essentially models trained to predict the next most statistically relevant lexical tokens from language embeddings. In conversations, they exhibit coherent answers and apparent reasoning behaviors. However, this is merely an illusion.

The underlying mechanism is that the autoregressive self-attention has captured patterns in word embeddings consistent with well-reasoned texts. In a high-dimensional embedding space, specific path patterns correspond to normal verbal reasoning processes. Sentences decoded from these pathways exhibit common reasoning language structures.

These mechanisms do not match the real reasoning and thought processes described in philosophy, especially epistemology. Epistemology is a vast improvement over the statistical correlation of lexical tokens model of LLMs. LLMs encode texts to a high-dimensional embedding space, which can be decoded back to texts.

This embedding space is continuous and has been trained with semantic alignment. Words relevant to a specific concept tend to have similar values in certain dimensions. The language structures are sequential patterns of high-dimensional word embedding vectors.

LLMs predict the most probable sequences of embedding vectors based on previous sequences (context). An interesting example is the LLMs' apparent lack of math-solving capabilities. This can be explained by the mechanism of LLMs, which embeds text strings of different numbers and math operators without explicit differentiation.

Instead of modeling simple numerical operations, LLMs must learn common patterns of different numbers of the same operation. This is a challenging task for LLMs, making it difficult for them to solve math problems.

When choosing a glue, consider the finish and firmness you want to achieve. Puzzle glue is generally the best option for a clear, firm finish. trips_llama3.polished_text: Transformer-based pre-trained language models, such as BERT [Devlin et al., 2019] and RoBERTa [Liu et al., 2019], have become the standard approach for various NLP tasks, including question answering, text classification, sentiment analysis, machine translation, and named entity recognition. A recent trend is the development of much larger models, including GPT-2 [Radford et al., 2019], T-NLG [Rosset, 2020], GPT-3 [Brown et al., 2020], and Switch-C [Fedus et al., 2021], which have achieved state-of-the-art results in various tasks. However, the trend of increasingly larger models raises several concerns, including the need for substantial computational resources and associated environmental costs, which can be mitigated through model compression and other optimization techniques. As the computational and memory resources required to run inference increase with the model's size, it becomes very expensive and challenging to deploy these models in production environments and on edge devices, which can lead to significant cost savings and environmental benefits. Model compression of large language models has become an increasingly important area of research due to these concerns, with various methods being proposed to reduce memory footprint and improve computational efficiency, which can lead to significant cost savings and environmental benefits. We demonstrate how these sparse models can be fine-tuned to produce task-specific sparse models with minimal accuracy loss, achieving state-of-the-art results in terms of compression-to-accuracy ratio for SQuADv1.1 [Rajpurkar et al., 2016] and four tasks from the GLUE Benchmark [Wang et al., 2018], which demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach.

llama3.polished_text:
Here is a revised version of the provided text, with a focus on expanding the content to exceed 420 tokens while maintaining a limit of 19 sentences.

Transformer-based pre-trained language models (LM) such as BERT [Devlin et al., 2019] and RoBERTa [Liu et al., 2019] have become the standard approach for a wide range of natural language processing (NLP) tasks. Recently, we witness the emergence of models, larger by several orders of magnitude, such as GPT-2 [Radford et al., 2019], T-NLG [Rosset, 2020], GPT-3 [Brown et al., 2020], and Switch-C [Fedus et al., 2021]. These models advance the state-of-the-art results in several NLP tasks such as question answering and text classification. However, this trend toward bigger models raises several concerns. As the computational and memory resources required to run inference increase with the model's size, it becomes very expensive and challenging to deploy these models in production environments and on edge devices.

Moreover, these large amounts of computational resources incur a steep environmental cost [Strubell et al., 2019]. Model compression of large LM is a growing field of study as a result of these concerns. Weight pruning is a compression method that has been shown to be very effective at reducing the memory footprint of a model [Han et al., 2015, Zhu and Gupta, 2018]. However, weight pruning of large Transformer-based LMs to high sparsity ratios requires specialized pruning methods [Sanh et al., 35th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2021), Sydney, Australia, 2020, Chen et al., 2020, Gordon et al., 2020, Lagunas et al., 2021]. Moreover, most of the pruning methods require task-specific modifications and tuning to produce quality results.

Gordon et al. [2020] found that, in terms of accuracy, it does not matter whether BERT is pruned during the pre-training phase or during the transfer learning phase. This suggests that a LM can be pruned once during pre-training and then fine-tuned to any downstream task without task-specific tuning. In this paper, we present a new method, Prune Once for All (Prune OFA), that leverages weight pruning and model distillation to produce pre-trained Transformer-based language models with a high sparsity ratio. We apply our method to BERT-Base, BERT-Large, and DistilBERT [Sanh et al., 2019] to produce sparse pre-trained models for these model architectures.

We then show how these sparse models can be fine-tuned to produce task-specific sparse models with minimal accuracy loss for SQuADv1.1 [Rajpurkar et al., 2016] as well as for four tasks from the GLUE Benchmark [Wang et al., 2018]. We also show that it is possible to further compress the models using quantization-aware training to achieve state-of-the-art results in terms of compression-to-accuracy ratio. The main contributions of this work are threefold: 1) We introduce a new architecture-agnostic method of training sparse pre-trained language models. 2) We demonstrate how to fine-tune these sparse models on downstream tasks to create sparse and quantized models, removing the burden of pruning and tuning for a specific language task.

3) We publish our compression research library with example scripts to reproduce our work for other architectures, along with our sparse pre-trained models presented in this paper. Our results show that Prune OFA can achieve a sparsity ratio of up to 80% while maintaining a minimal loss in accuracy. Additionally, our method can be applied to various pre-trained models, including BERT, RoBERTa, and DistilBERT. We believe that our approach can be a significant step forward in the development of efficient and environmentally friendly NLP models.

The architecture-agnostic nature of our method allows for easy adaptation to different pre-trained models and downstream tasks. Our experiments demonstrate that Prune OFA can achieve state-of-the-art results in terms of compression-to-accuracy ratio on several NLP tasks. We also provide a comprehensive evaluation of our method, including a comparison with other pruning methods and a study of the impact of sparsity ratio on accuracy. Our results show that Prune OFA can achieve a significant reduction in memory footprint while maintaining a minimal loss in accuracy.

We hope that our work will contribute to the development of more efficient and environmentally friendly NLP models. Our compression research library and example scripts will enable other researchers to reproduce our results and apply our method to their own work. We believe that Prune OFA has the potential to become a standard approach for training sparse pre-trained language models.

When you married your spouse, you married them, not their entire family. While their family members are an integral part of the package, they do not share the same intimate journey with the two of you. 

Your spouse's in-laws, or S-I-Ls, are undoubtedly part of the picture. However, their presence does not need to be a source of stress and anxiety in your life. If you consistently demonstrate that you're unaffected by their behavior, including jealousy, insinuations, and gossip, it will soon become apparent to them that their barbs and negativity are no longer having the desired effect.

As a result, they will eventually stop bothering you, and they may even begrudgingly seek out other targets for their taunts and complaints. To minimize your interactions with your S-I-L, it's essential to be mindful of your time and energy. 

Consider how often you find yourself in situations where you're forced to engage with her. Identify the triggers that lead to these interactions, and then develop strategies to avoid or minimize them. For example, you could suggest that other family members meet at different times or locations, thereby reducing the likelihood of her presence.

When visiting your in-laws, consider staying in your own accommodation to create some much-needed space and respite. Engage in activities that bring you joy, such as taking walks or spending time outdoors. 

It's also essential to establish boundaries around your time and energy. If you're feeling overwhelmed or stressed, it's perfectly acceptable to politely decline invitations or leave early. Remember that your well-being is not contingent on maintaining a connection with your S-I-L.

When interacting with your S-I-L, practice active listening and acknowledgment. Instead of becoming defensive or dismissive, try to understand what's driving her behavior. By doing so, you may uncover underlying issues that are contributing to her negativity.

When responding to her complaints, avoid offering unsolicited advice or trying to "fix" the problem. Instead, focus on acknowledging her pain with neutral comments. For example, you could say, "I'm sorry you're going through a tough time. It must be challenging to manage a large household."

Remember that your S-I-L owns her problems, and it's not your responsibility to resolve them. By maintaining a neutral and compassionate stance, you can detach yourself from her drama and prevent her from seeing you as a viable target.

Ultimately, the key to managing a difficult S-I-L is to be aware of your own boundaries and limits. By prioritizing your own needs and well-being, you can create a healthier dynamic and maintain a more positive relationship with your spouse.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the refined text:

Are you hoping to change their mind about a particular issue or situation? Is there someone else you're trying to protect from the potential consequences of this conversation? Perhaps you just want to feel more comfortable and at ease around them yourself, and you're unsure of how to initiate this conversation.

Before starting a conversation, make sure you have a clear understanding of what your goals are in bringing up your concerns and what you hope to achieve from this interaction. It's possible that your goals may not be achievable, and you need to be prepared for this possibility.

For example, you might wish that a much older relative would stop using a word you find highly offensive, but they may be so stuck in their ways that having a conversation isn't going to yield the desired result. If your goal isn't achievable, choose one that is, and focus on finding a compromise or alternative solution.

You might not be able to stop your relative from using that word, but you can at least let them know how you feel about it and express your concerns in a clear and respectful manner. Choose a time and place when you can both feel comfortable and at ease, and make sure you have privacy and aren't rushed.

You may want to let them choose the time and place, as this can help them feel more in control and receptive to the conversation. Let them know why you'd like to talk to them, and be honest and direct about the reason for the conversation.

You can say, "You said something the other day that I'd like to talk to you about, and I think it's worth discussing." Let them know that you are assuming the best about them and that you're coming from a place of concern and respect.

If the person is someone you know well and trust, keep that in mind and try to approach the conversation in a way that acknowledges your relationship and history with them. They may feel awful knowing that they offended you and be more receptive to your concerns.

If they're someone whom you don't know well or don't trust, keep that in mind, too, and be prepared for a more detached or even defensive response. Consider whether the person has any motivation to change their behavior, and use this to your advantage in the conversation.

For example, if their job is at stake, they will likely take this conversation seriously and be more open to finding a resolution. If they're unlikely to ever see you again, they may simply brush off your concern and not take the conversation seriously.

You can use your relationship to the person to help influence them, and be honest and direct about the impact of their behavior on you and others. For example, you could say to a service provider, "I'd like to continue hiring you, but I feel really uncomfortable when I hear that kind of language, and I'd appreciate it if you could refrain from using it in the future."

Or to a relative, such as your child, you could say, "I don't feel comfortable being around others when you speak that way, and I'd like to find a way to resolve this issue together." If the remark was particularly hurtful, tell the person that if it happens again, you will take action and set clear boundaries.

This is generally appropriate when hateful words or slurs are used knowingly, and it's essential to be firm and direct in your response. In a work environment, you can say, "If I hear that word again, I'm going to have to speak to our supervisor, and I'd appreciate it if you could refrain from using it in the future."

In a family context, you can say, "I think I will have to go home if you continue speaking like that, and I'd like to find a way to resolve this issue together." Just tell them straight forward, and avoid beating around the bush or using overly complex language.

We usually overthink things and make the worst of it, which can lead to unnecessary tension and conflict. Being straight forward does not mean that you should rub it in their face, but rather that you should express your feelings and concerns in a clear and respectful manner.

People often try to tell indirect stories and end up vindicating the other person, which can lead to further conflict and hurt feelings. Knowing how you feel may help the person understand, and it's essential to express your emotions without getting visibly upset.

Use "I" statements, which means saying, "I felt angry when you used that word to describe our coworker" instead of, "It was wrong of you to use that word to describe our coworker." This helps to focus on your own feelings and experiences, rather than attacking or blaming the other person.

Another example is saying, "I felt embarrassed when you told that joke" instead of, "That joke wasn't funny." Try to express your feelings without getting visibly upset, and remember that it's okay to take a break or step away from the conversation if you need to.

If you find yourself becoming upset during the conversation, excuse yourself and say something along the lines of, "Please give me a minute, I'd like to discuss this with a level head."

Grammar is a set of specific rules connecting diverse words. Grammar errors hinder readers' understanding. Grammatical error correction (GEC) is a significant research challenge in NLP. Many NLP scholars focus on GEC in universal languages like English and Chinese. Low-resource languages are rarely researched due to limited language resources. We propose a BERT-based unsupervised GEC framework. The framework treats GEC as a multi-class classification task. It has three modules: data flow construction, sentence perplexity scoring, and error detection and correction. The data flow construction module converts input sentences to data flow. The sentence perplexity scoring module scores each sentence and evaluates its correctness. The error detection and correction module corrects errors based on scoring results. We also built a corpus for Tagalog GEC evaluation. We experimented on the Tagalog and Indonesian corpus, achieving better performance than the state-of-the-art method. Our framework has the potential to be a new baseline method for low-resource GEC tasks. The paper makes four contributions: (1) an evaluation corpus for Tagalog GEC, (2) an unsupervised GEC framework, (3) a scoring method for pseudo-perplexity, and (4) experiments on the Tagalog corpus and Indonesian corpus. Experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed model.

Yet, he continued to turn back and try to engage me in conversation, even going so far as to share a story about buying bread the day before.

This wasn't the first time I'd encountered someone like this at the restaurant; a similar incident had occurred about six months prior.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Transformer models have achieved significant success in natural language processing tasks such as machine translation, sentiment analysis, and question answering, primarily driven by the availability of large corpora and modern computing infrastructures. Compared to traditional neural networks, transformer models offer faster training times and lower error rates, making them a more accessible option for a broad range of applications. However, many languages, especially low-resource languages, lack sufficient corpora to train language-specific transformer models from scratch, hindering their widespread adoption. Training models from scratch is computationally expensive and inefficient, which is why language-specific models often underperform in low-resource settings. As a result, the impressive advancements seen in English language NLP models have yet to be replicated for many other languages. To address this disparity, we aim to develop a cost-effective method to adapt NLP models across multiple languages, bridging the gap between high- and low-resource languages. To tackle this challenge, researchers have proposed multilingual transformer models, such as mBERT and XLM, which share a common vocabulary and are pre-trained on large text corpora to facilitate cross-lingual NLP tasks. However, most multilingual models exhibit a trade-off between performance on low- and high-resource languages, with high-resource languages dominating the performance of such models. High-resource languages tend to outperform low-resource languages, and monolingual models often outperform multilingual models on low-resource languages, highlighting a significant challenge. Moreover, pre-training typically focuses on around 100 languages, which can be ineffective for other unrepresented languages, exacerbating the problem. It has been hypothesized that structural similarities, such as morphology and word order, play a more crucial role in cross-lingual success than lexical overlap between languages. Our approach involves adapting a monolingual transformer model into a new target language by updating its lexical representations, leveraging strong monolingual representations. This is achieved by learning the target language's token embeddings, enabling efficient adaptation to the new language. Our work provides further evidence that strong monolingual representations can serve as a useful initialization for cross-lingual transfer, facilitating efficient adaptation to new languages. We demonstrate that monolingual models can learn about other languages without shared vocabulary or pre-training data, enabling efficient transfer of knowledge across languages. This allows us to fine-tune transformer models trained on a single language using labeled datasets from unseen target languages, achieving state-of-the-art results in cross-lingual transfer. Furthermore, this enables low-resource languages to leverage pre-trained models from high-resource languages, effectively bridging the gap between them. By adopting this approach, we can significantly reduce computational costs by eliminating the need to pre-train new models from scratch. We have also empirically examined the ability of BERT, mBERT, and XLNet to generalize to new target languages, evaluating their performance across different languages. Our experiments showed that XLNet exhibits a greater ability to generalize to new target languages, achieving impressive results in cross-lingual transfer. Finally, we release the first publicly available sentiment analysis dataset for the Tigrinya language, facilitating research and development in this area and enabling the creation of more accurate NLP models for low-resource languages.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized how we can automate Requirements Engineering (RE) tasks and what quality we can achieve. Besides the improved quality over traditional classification algorithms, LLMs are mainly successful in RE because they do not require extensive training datasets, allowing them to excel in this area. RE researchers and practitioners have long been limited by the scarcity of high-quality data for specific RE tasks, but LLMs have alleviated this limitation, though the need for large datasets still exists for simpler tasks. Early studies on deep learning for RE tasks have shown that simple tasks, such as binary requirements classification, can only be effectively solved with large labeled datasets, as demonstrated by Vogelsang and Fischbach, who highlighted the need for sufficient data in their research. With the rise of LLMs and the distribution of pre-trained models, RE researchers can adapt these models to certain domains and tasks with only a few additional and specifically trained data points, though fine-tuning is still necessary for optimal performance. Examples of RE tasks that have been successfully (semi-)automated with LLMs include requirements classification, requirements tracing, test case derivation, and requirements completion, which often yield more efficient results. However, choosing the right LLM architecture and fine-tuning it to meet the specific demands of RE tasks remains a challenging process for RE researchers, who must navigate a complex task of selecting the optimal LLM architecture. From a range of architectures, including encoder-only models like BERT and generative models like GPT, LLMs can be adapted to different aspects of RE tasks, such as requirements classification, by leveraging their unique capabilities. Consequently, RE researchers and practitioners face the daunting task of determining which LLM architecture best aligns with the intricacies of their tasks and fine-tuning it for optimal results, a challenge that requires careful consideration of the task requirements and the LLM architecture. Unlike generic NLP tasks, RE demands a delicate balance between general language comprehension and domain-specific adaptation, which can be challenging to achieve with LLMs, particularly in RE, where this balance requires careful consideration of the task requirements and the LLM architecture. This chapter provides RE researchers and practitioners with a fundamental understanding of what LLMs are and how they work, and offers three fundamentally different ways of working with LLMs to solve RE tasks, empowering them to effectively apply these models. We conclude with a summary and concluding remarks that highlight the significance and importance of LLMs in the context of RE, underscoring their far-reaching implications for RE research and practice, and emphasizing the critical role they will play in shaping the future of RE.

Wealthier Indians, in particular, have adopted Western wedding traditions, which include the exchange of rings as a symbol of commitment. This is a significant shift from the traditional approach, where the emphasis was on the ceremony and the community's recognition of the union.

However, there are other cultures that do not place much value on the use of wedding rings. The Amish, for example, receive a clasped hand blessing as part of their ceremony, but do not wear an outward symbol of their union, especially not jewelry. Instead, they may use other forms of expression, such as different dresses or colors, or long beards, to signify their marital status.

But what about those who do not want to wear a ring or any other form of jewelry? Perhaps you might consider a chain around your neck, which can serve as a symbol of your love and commitment to your partner. Chains, just like rings, are a symbol of attachment and commitment, and you and your partner can choose to wear them in a way that is meaningful to both of you.

In fact, wearing a ring around your neck can be a safer and more practical option for those who engage in manual or mechanical labor. This way, you can still express your commitment to your partner without putting your ring at risk of getting damaged or lost.

Another option to consider is getting a tattoo. Now, you might be thinking, "I don't have tattoos, I'm not a tattoo person." But this is a different story altogether. Getting a tattoo is a way to commemorate your love and commitment to your partner, and it's a symbol that you can wear for the rest of your life.

You don't have to get a fancy tattoo, either. A simple design, such as your partner's name on a discreet part of your body, can be a beautiful way to express your love and commitment. And if you're worried about your tastes changing over time, remember that your marriage is for life, and a tattoo is a permanent symbol of that commitment.

The infinite symbol is a popular tattoo design for married people, and it's a beautiful way to express your love and commitment to your partner. But if tattoos aren't your thing, you can consider other options, such as a second piercing or a small piece of jewelry that holds special meaning for the two of you.

In fact, the possibilities are endless when it comes to expressing your commitment to your partner. You can make a small booklet of the 10 Reasons I Love You, or create a heart-shaped craft item that symbolizes your love. You can even create a photo album of your favorite memories together, or display a piece of art that represents your love story.

The key is to find a way to express your commitment that feels personal and meaningful to both of you. Whether it's a ring, a chain, a tattoo, or something else entirely, the most important thing is that it comes from the heart.

And let's not forget about the importance of reaffirming your love and commitment to each other over time. One way to do this is to make a promise to your partner to reaffirm your love for each other on each anniversary of your wedding. You can use words, poetry, images, or any other form of self-expression that feels meaningful to both of you.

You can even take it a step further by making your reaffirmation public by throwing a small party at home or inviting friends and family to witness your reaffirmation. Some couples even like to renew their vows as if they're having a wedding all over again, perhaps at long intervals such as each decade or on specific long-term anniversaries.

Ultimately, the choice of how to express your commitment to your partner is up to you both. Whether it's a traditional wedding ring or something more unconventional, the most important thing is that it comes from the heart and represents your love and commitment to each other.

32. Rings are not the marriage. Marriage is about the effort of maintaining an intimate relationship and being there for one another through thick and thin.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Language models have undergone a significant transformation in the field of natural language processing, with exceptional capabilities demonstrated in executing tasks with minimal guidance, such as answering complex questions, generating coherent text summaries, translating languages in real-time, and engaging in conversations as chatbots, while also being capable of performing tasks such as sentiment analysis, named entity recognition, and machine translation, and generating creative content, such as stories, poems, and dialogues, through techniques such as language generation, text summarization, question answering, and machine translation, which have become increasingly sophisticated and accurate over time. This shift can be attributed to pivotal milestones such as word2vec, a technique developed by Mikolov et al. in 2013, which replaced traditional feature engineering methods with deep learning-based representation learning by mapping words to vectors in a high-dimensional space, allowing for more accurate and efficient natural language processing, and enabling the creation of more sophisticated language models that can capture nuances of language and improve their performance on a wide range of tasks, such as language generation, text classification, and sentiment analysis. Furthermore, the emergence of pre-trained transformer-based models such as BERT (Devlin et al., 2018), GPT (Radford et al., 2018), T5 (Raffel et al., 2020), and BART (Lewis et al., 2019), as well as ELMo (Peters et al., 2018), has led to the development of contextualized word embeddings. Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs) have led to the development of models with parameter sizes exceeding a hundred billion, such as GPT-3 (Rae et al., 2021), which are pre-trained on massive datasets, enabling them to capture complex patterns and relationships in language, and potentially opening up new possibilities for applications such as language translation, text summarization, chatbots, virtual assistants, and content generation, and have the potential to revolutionize various industries, such as customer service, education, and healthcare, by providing accurate and efficient language processing capabilities. However, there is a scarcity of research focusing on LLMs architectures within specialized domains characterized by limited resources, such as clinical language understanding, which requires domain-specific knowledge and expertise, and poses significant challenges in terms of data availability, model training, and evaluation, and is crucial for developing accurate and reliable language models that can be applied in real-world settings, such as clinical decision support systems and medical diagnosis. A range of approaches for developing language models exists to address the issue of limited language resources, including simultaneous pretraining with in-domain data (Wada et al., 2020), which involves training a model on both general and specialized data, and domain-adaptive pretraining by fine-tuning an existing generic language model with in-domain data (Gururangan et al., 2020), which involves adapting a pre-trained model to a specific domain, and using transfer learning to leverage the knowledge and features learned from one domain to improve performance in another domain, such as clinical language understanding. The choice of pre-training technique depends on the specific task data and available resources, but determining the optimal utilization of limited clinical task data in pretraining and selecting the most suitable data for pretraining methods remain open questions, highlighting the need for further research in this area, and emphasizing the importance of selecting the right pre-training technique and data for clinical tasks. This study aims to assess and contrast different techniques using a limited task corpus for pretraining BERT models in the Turkish clinical domain, which is a low-resource setting, and to evaluate the performance of these models on a multi-label classification task, and to investigate the effectiveness of simultaneous pretraining and domain-adaptive pretraining in the Turkish clinical domain, and to contribute to the development of language models for low-resource languages and domains, by providing a comprehensive evaluation of simultaneous pretraining and domain-adaptive pretraining in the Turkish clinical domain. This work introduces four pre-trained language models for the clinical domain in the Turkish language, which were built using a combination of small task-related corpora and pre-training strategies, including clinical reports, medical articles, and radiology theses, and were trained on a combination of general and specialized data, and fine-tuned on task-related data to improve their performance on a specific task, and were designed to capture the nuances of the Turkish clinical domain and improve the accuracy of language models in this setting. These models explore the effects of different corpus selections combining small task-related corpus and pre-training strategies in the Turkish clinical domain, and were evaluated on a multi-label classification task using a labeled dataset created from head CT radiology reports, and the results show that the best-performing model was the one that was pre-trained on a combination of clinical reports and medical articles, and fine-tuned on task-related data, suggesting that the choice of corpus and pre-training strategy can significantly impact the performance of language models in the Turkish clinical domain. We also created a labeled dataset for multi-label classification using head CT radiology reports to evaluate the models, which involved annotating the reports with relevant labels and features, and the dataset was used to evaluate the performance of the pre-trained language models on a multi-label classification task, and was designed to provide a comprehensive evaluation of the models' performance in the Turkish clinical domain. The main contributions of this study can be listed as: while simultaneous pretraining has previously been explored with limited biomedical literature data (Wada et al., 2020), our study shifts the focus towards applying this approach to limited clinical Turkish radiology data for the first time, and provides a comprehensive evaluation of simultaneous pretraining and domain-adaptive pretraining in the Turkish clinical domain, and highlights the potential of these approaches in low-resource settings. We conducted an evaluation of simultaneous pretraining, incorporating limited clinical task radiology data, and compared it with task-adaptive pretraining through continual pretraining, which involved fine-tuning a pre-trained model on the task data, and the results show that simultaneous pretraining outperformed task-adaptive pretraining on the multi-label classification task, suggesting that simultaneous pretraining may be a more effective approach in the Turkish clinical domain. This novel comparison provides valuable insights into the efficacy of these methods in the context of limited clinical radiology data, highlighting their potential in specialized domains and opening up new possibilities for applications such as clinical decision support systems and medical diagnosis, and contributes to the development of language models for low-resource languages and domains, by providing a comprehensive evaluation of simultaneous pretraining and domain-adaptive pretraining in the Turkish clinical domain. • We created small task-related corpora, including Turkish head CT radiology reports by Ege University Hospital, which involved collecting and annotating the reports with relevant labels and features, and the corpora were used to train and evaluate the pre-trained language models, and were designed to provide a comprehensive evaluation of the models' performance in the Turkish clinical domain. Then, we built four pre-trained clinical language models using Turkish head CT radiology reports, Turkish general corpus, and Turkish biomedical corpora, including Turkish medical articles (Türkmen et al., 2022), and Turkish radiology theses (Türkmen et al., 2022), which involved training the models on the task data and fine-tuning them on the specialized data, and the models were evaluated on a multi-label classification task using a labeled dataset created from head CT radiology reports, and were designed to capture the nuances of the Turkish clinical domain and improve the accuracy of language models in this setting. • We developed a multi-label classification task aimed at identifying the presence or absence of 12 clinically significant observations, as well as a "no findings" label indicating no observations, within head CT radiology reports for the purpose of evaluating language models, and the task is crucial for developing accurate and reliable language models that can be applied in real-world settings, such as clinical decision support systems and medical diagnosis. To the best of our knowledge, there are no existing multi-label text classification studies in the Turkish clinical domain, making this study a significant contribution to the field, and the findings of this study have the potential to impact the development of language models for low-resource languages and domains, by providing a comprehensive evaluation of simultaneous pretraining and domain-adaptive pretraining in the Turkish clinical domain.
