llama3.polished_text:
Language models have undergone a significant transformation in the field of natural language processing, with exceptional capabilities demonstrated in executing tasks with minimal guidance. This shift can be attributed to pivotal milestones such as word2vec (Mikolov et al., 2013), which replaced feature engineering methods with deep learning-based representation learning. Furthermore, the emergence of pre-trained transformer-based models such as BERT (Devlin et al., 2018), GPT (Radford et al., 2018), T5 (Raffel et al., 2020), and BART (Lewis et al., 2019) has led to the development of contextualized word embeddings.

Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs) have led to the development of models with parameter sizes exceeding a hundred billion, such as GPT-3 (Rae et al., 2021), which are pre-trained on massive datasets. However, there is a scarcity of research focusing on LLMs architectures within specialized domains characterized by limited resources. A range of approaches for developing language models exists to address the issue of limited language resources, including simultaneous pretraining with in-domain data (Wada et al., 2020) and domain-adaptive pretraining by fine-tuning an existing generic language model with in-domain data (Gururangan et al., 2020).

The choice of pre-training technique depends on the specific task data and available resources, but determining the optimal utilization of limited clinical task data in pretraining and selecting the most suitable data for pretraining methods remain open questions. This study aims to assess and contrast different techniques using a limited task corpus for pretraining BERT models in the Turkish clinical domain, which is a low-resource setting. This work introduces four pre-trained language models for the clinical domain in the Turkish language. These models explore the effects of different corpus selections combining small task-related corpus and pretraining strategies in the Turkish clinical domain.

We also created a labeled dataset for multi-label classification using head CT radiology reports to evaluate the models. The main contributions can be listed as:

• While simultaneous pretraining has previously been explored with limited biomedical literature data in the work of (Wada et al., 2020), our study shifts the focus towards applying this approach to limited clinical Turkish radiology data for the first time. This marks a significant departure from previous research, which has primarily focused on leveraging large datasets for pretraining.

• We conducted an evaluation of simultaneous pretraining, incorporating limited clinical task radiology data, and compared it with task-adaptive pretraining through continual pretraining. This novel comparison provides valuable insights into the efficacy of these methods in the context of limited clinical radiology data, highlighting their potential in specialized domains.

• We created small task-related corpora, including Turkish head CT radiology reports by Ege University Hospital. This corpus serves as the foundation for our pretraining experiments, allowing us to evaluate the performance of BERT models in a real-world clinical setting.

• We built four pre-trained clinical language models, for the first time, using Turkish head CT radiology reports, Turkish general corpus, and Turkish biomedical corpora, including Turkish medical articles (Türkmen et al., 2022), and Turkish radiology theses (Türkmen et al., 2022). These models are designed to capture the nuances of the Turkish language and the clinical domain, enabling them to perform well in tasks such as multi-label classification.

• We developed a multi-label classification task aimed at identifying the presence or absence of 12 clinically significant observations, as well as a "no findings" label indicating no observations, within head CT radiology reports for the purpose of evaluating language models. This task is particularly relevant in the Turkish clinical domain, where accurate diagnosis and classification are critical.

To the best of our knowledge, there are no existing multi-label text classification studies in the Turkish clinical domain. Our work addresses this gap by providing a comprehensive evaluation of language models in this domain, shedding light on their potential applications and limitations. The results of our study demonstrate the effectiveness of simultaneous pretraining and task-adaptive pretraining in the Turkish clinical domain, highlighting the importance of selecting the optimal pretraining technique for a given task and dataset.

Furthermore, our study contributes to the development of language models in low-resource languages and domains, which is a critical area of research in natural language processing. By extending the scope of language models to include specialized domains and languages, we can unlock new applications and use cases, ultimately benefiting a wider range of users. Our work serves as a foundation for future research in this area, encouraging the exploration of novel pretraining techniques and the development of more sophisticated language models.

Here's a refined version of the text, condensed to fewer than 420 tokens and ensuring each sentence has more than three tokens:

Large Language Models have garnered significant attention in recent years, with GPT-4 being one of the most prominent examples, as tracked in the LLMSYS Chatbot Arena Leaderboard. 

However, other models demonstrate impressive performance in various tasks, such as those presented at the dl4kg2023 workshop at ISWC in November 2023, held in Athens, Greece. 

In the field of Knowledge Graph Engineering (KGE), the overarching task is to structure knowledge and encode it in a machine-processable format. 

Machine learning techniques for creating or processing knowledge graphs are a well-researched topic, receiving new momentum due to their relevance, as emphasized by the Dagstuhl Seminar 22372 and the Knowledge Base Construction from Pretrained Language Models (LM-KBC) Challenge. 

Pan et al. [3] outline the potential of connecting Large Language Models (LLMs) and Knowledge Graphs (KGs) using "LLM-augmented KGs." 

To represent Knowledge Graphs, RDF (the Resource Description Framework) serves as a standard, while Turtle, a textual representation, is widely used to store and exchange RDF data. 

We opted for Turtle due to its natural language resemblance, aligning well with the primary mode of interaction with LLMs. 

In previous works, we conducted manual experiments and introduced the framework LLM-KG-Bench for automated benchmarking of LLM performance on KGE tasks. 

This paper expands upon that work by introducing two new tasks to the LLM-KG-Bench framework and evaluating various models' ability to parse, comprehend, analyze, create, and serialize RDF knowledge graphs using Turtle serialization. 

We include Claude 1.3-100k, GPT-3.5 Turbo, GPT-4, Claude 2, GPT4All Vicuna, and Falcon 13B in our evaluation to assess their strengths and weaknesses for RDF KGE workflows using Turtle. 

We describe related work in the next section, introduce the benchmark tasks in section 3, explain the study setup and present the evaluation in section 4, and conclude with a discussion and future work in section 5.
